LONDON, Printed for Daniel Brown at the Bible without Temple-Barr; and John Walthoe, at his Shop in Vine-Court, Middle-Temple, 1695.

div.head: PROLOGUE, By a FRIEND.
div.l: I'th' latter Age, ere Criticks dar'd to Damn,
Or Censure rashly, what deserv'd a Name;
When Bully Ben lugg'd out in Cat'line's Cause,
And huff'd his duller Audience to Applause,
Then if the Poet swore 'twas good, each Guest
Believ'd the Author, and approv'd the Feast:
But now in humble Prologue, the poor Muse
Implores your favour, and for mercy sues.
To day the ty'rd Satyr takes his rest,
And has at last himself a Fool confest:
In vain is all his Malice, or his Art,
He jerks, you grin, and damn him when you smart.
This Ag's Crimes are past good Satyrs Cure,
He scarce can lash you more than you'll endure.
The busie States-man, can in a well-writ Scene
See Treason punish'd, and yet Plots again:
Young Gaming Heirs, who see poor Cully trickt,
Laugh at the Jest, and the same Night are nickt.
The London Cuckold sees his Brother Horn'd,
Yet is not by the Stage-Example warn'd.
The high kept Miss can see poor Jiltals fate,
Yet Cuckolds her kind Keeper for a Treat:
Since Headlong Folly then uncheck'd will reign,
Successful Satyr but Rebels in vain▪
Our harmless Author therefore bid me say,
That ev'n Fopp'ry goes untouch'd to day;
There's scarce a knotted Fringe in all his Play.
The stately Side-Box Beau may cock his Nose,
And Mob'd up Phillis take a Morning Dose
Of fifty Dishes at the Choc'late-House.
And when the Consort's done, the Ladies may
There entertain the Beaux till break of day,
And still pretend they for their Coaches stay.
Men of no bus'ness to the Court may come,
And Essenc'd Wigs Perfume the Drawing Room;
Where, on the Window, Fops, their Wit to prove,
Write Petty-Treason to the God of Love.
In short, whatever Crimes o'r run the Town,
Here's none to day that are with Malice shown:
We've Plot and Humour too, but as for Wit,
Let that be judg'd by the discerning Pit.

div.head: THE EPISTLE DEDICATORY TO Rowland Eyre Esq.
div.p: IT has long been a Custom with Authors to trouble their best Friends; for, who but friends will excuse so many Impertinencies as are generally found in Dedications, and have their Names set as a Skreen betwixt our faults and the censures of the Criticks, who in this Age are so unmerciful, that they never spare the Poet for sake of the Patron, be he never so eminent or well qualify'd?

A second pretence, is a grateful acknowledment of favours receiv'd; but there Self-Interest advances under the Mask of Gratitude and good Manners, for our thanks seem rather invitations to new Benefits. To say truth, Poets choose Patrons for their Plays, with the same design that crafty Parents do able Godfathers for their Children.

The Reasons, Sir, why I shelter this under your Name, are, because your Affability, and singular good Disposition to all Mankind, enclines you not only to pardon Errors, but to confer Obligations, which you perform with that cheerfulness and courtesie, that whom you oblige you charm. Next, Sir, from the long acquaintance and vicinity of our Families and Relations, who ever held a fair and happy Correspondence till the vicissitudes of time gave Interruption. Then let this tender of my respects and service to you, with this small trifle, receive and establish me in your Memory and Friendship, which is the aim and ambition of, Sir,

closer.signed: Your sincere Friend, and most humble Servant, Edward Ravenscroft

Second Innkeeper, and Jack Sawce a Cook.

div.head: THE Canterbury Guests; OR, A Bargain Broken.
ACT I.
SCENE I.
div.stage: Enter Alderman, Fur, and Justice Greedy.

sp.speaker: Fur.
sp.p: MR. Justice, this was kindly done of you, to come and meet us.

sp.speaker: Gree.
sp.p: Since I knew of your coming into the Country, I could not do less than ride out a Mile or two, and now, Mr. Alderman, you are welcome to Canterbury.

sp.speaker: Fur.
sp.p: Sir, I thank you.

sp.speaker: Gree.
sp.p: What! are not your Daughter and Neice light out of the Coach yet?

sp.speaker: Fur.
sp.p: I bid 'em stay till we had determin'd which Inn to lodge at, where is the best entertainment?

sp.speaker: Gree.
sp.p: Let me see, there is the Three Kings, and there the Old Kings Head. I protest this Riding out has got me a Stomach; I'll see which House has the best provisions, and we'll take up there.

sp.speaker: Fur.
sp.p: Do so; in the mean time I'll step to the Coachman and pay him.

sp.speaker: Gree.
sp.p: And order my Man to have my Horse home. Fur. Exit.

sp.speaker: 1 Inn.
sp.p: Speak in the Star there, Tapster.

sp.speaker: 2 Inn.
sp.p: Chamberlain, show up into the Rose, quickly.

sp.speaker: 1 Inn.
sp.p: Mr. Justice.

sp.speaker: 2 Inn.
sp.p: Mr. Greedy.

sp.speaker: 1 Inn.
sp.p: I see, Sir, you have a Coach full of Friends come to Town, please to let 'em be my guests, they shall have civil entertainment.

sp.speaker: 2 Inn.
sp.p: Sir, here they may have excellent accommodation.

sp.speaker: 1 Inn.
sp.p: Mr. Justice. They pull him by the Sleue.

sp.speaker: 2 Inn.
sp.p: Sir.

sp.speaker: Greed.
sp.p: Look you Neighbours, all favour and affection set aside, what have you to Eat and Drink, what curiosity have you for Supper, there's the point?

sp.speaker: 1 Inn.
sp.p: For Wine, Sir, I have such a Pipe of Canary pierc'd but this Morning—

sp.speaker: Gree.
sp.p: Right Racy Canary.

sp.speaker: 1 Inn.
sp.p: Three Years old, as full of Nits as the Sun is of Motes, sparkling, as t'were the extract of Diamonds.

sp.speaker: Gree.
sp.p: Say'st thou.

sp.speaker: 1 Inn.
sp.p: 'Twill make a Cat speak, a Judge deaf and dumb, an old Man get Children, or bring a Dead Man to life again. 'Tis a Flower Mr. Justice.

sp.speaker: 2 Inn.
sp.p: I have such a Butt of Malago, Rich Old Malago.

sp.speaker: Gree.
sp.p: Old Malago!

sp.speaker: 2 Inn.
sp.p: And such a Butt of Sherry!

sp.speaker: Gree.
sp.p: Sherry too, and Old Malago! there's a double blessing; let me tast—

sp.speaker: 1 Inn.
sp.p: Then if you are for Claret, Sir— All this Scene they turn the Justice by the Arm from one to the other, with greater violence every time.

sp.speaker: 2 Inn.
sp.p: Or for White— Sir.

sp.speaker: Inn.
sp.p: I have such—

sp.speaker: 2 Inn.
sp.p: Not the like in England.

sp.speaker: Gree.
sp.p: Hold, hold Friends, all this is very well, what have you not that's Eatable.

sp.speaker: 1 Inn.
sp.p: You may have Mutton—

sp.speaker: 2 Inn.
sp.p: Or Lamb—

sp.speaker: 1 Inn.
sp.p: Or Rabbits—

sp.speaker: 2 Inn.
sp.p: Or Chickens—

sp.speaker: 1 Inn.
sp.p: Or Pidgeons—

sp.speaker: 2 Inn.
sp.p: Some young Turkeys, Sir, some young Turkeys.

sp.speaker: 1 Inn.
sp.p: Or a Pig, a Pig, a delicate fat white Sow Pig.

sp.speaker: Greed▪
sp.p: Pig— Pig— delicious meat.

sp.speaker: 2 Inn.
sp.p: Sir, I have three brace of the plumpest young Patridge.

sp.speaker: Gree.
sp.p: Young Patridge!

sp.speaker: 1 Inn.
sp.p: And I a brace of the rarest Pheasants.

sp.speaker: 2 Inn.
sp.p: Mr. Justice, I have such a rarity, such a morsel of Meat.

sp.speaker: Gree.
sp.p: What's that, what's that?

sp.speaker: 2 Inn.
sp.p: I had a whole live Calf sent me from Flanders, and within you may see such a Chine of Gaunt Veal—

sp.speaker: Gree.
sp.p: Gaunt Veal! O blessing sent from Heaven! let me go—

sp.speaker: 1 Inn.
sp.p: Mr. Justice. Holds the Justice.

sp.speaker: Gree.
sp.p: Let me go, or I'll lay you by the Heels.

sp.speaker: 2 Inn.
sp.p: 'Twere Treason to let you go, without acquainting your worship.

sp.speaker: Gree.
sp.p: Bear witness, he assaults me in the Highway.

sp.speaker: 1 Inn.
sp.p: That I have half a dozen of the finest largest Bruges Capons, that were ever sent a present into England.

sp.speaker: Gree.
sp.p: Bruges Capons!

sp.speaker: 2 Inn.
sp.p: They were fed with Marrow, Amber Greece, and blanch'd Almonds.

sp.speaker: Gree.
sp.p: Let me down on my knees and give thanks,— I am in the Land of Canaan.— O Bounty,— bounty,— bounty.—

sp.speaker: 1 and 2.
sp.p: Get up Sir.

sp.speaker: Gree.
sp.p: Which way shall I turn me.

sp.speaker: 1 Inn.
sp.p: This way Sir.

sp.speaker: 2 Inn.
sp.p: Here Sir.

sp.speaker: 1 Inn.
sp.p: This way Sir.

sp.speaker: 2 Inn.
sp.p: Here Sir.

sp.speaker: 1 Inn.
sp.p: Here's the Gaunt Veal.

sp.speaker: 2 Inn.
sp.p: Here the Bruges Capons.

sp.speaker: Gree.
sp.p: Stand off, let me go, let me go, O Gaunt Veal, Runs one way: veal, veal— O Bruges Capons, capon, capon, Runs t'other way. O Veal— O Capon, Capon, O Veal. Runs too and fro, several times.

sp.speaker: Fur.
sp.p: What's the matter, what's come to you?

sp.speaker: Gree.
sp.p: They have undone me,— I starve in the middle of plenty. I know not which to choose; A pox on you, joyn both your Houses together, O Capon! O Veal!— O Veal!— O Capon!

sp.speaker: 1 Inn.
sp.p: Sir, I have this day come down by the London Coach, a basket of your little round Marrow puddings.

sp.speaker: Gree.
sp.p: What, your white puddings, made of Marrow and Almonds?

sp.speaker: 1 Inn.
sp.p: They'l melt in your Mouth Sir—

sp.speaker: Gree.
sp.p: London Marrow puddings,— the scales are turn'd; and now Mr. Alderman, let's in and feast like Epicures, Gaunt Veal— and Marrow puddings.

sp.speaker: Fur.
sp.p: Come let's have Supper in good time.

sp.speaker: 2 Inn.
sp.p: You shall Sir. Ex. Fur. Greed. and 2 Innkeepers.

sp.speaker: 2 Inn.
sp.p: A pox of those Marrow puddings, I have lost my Guests, but it pleases me to think how the hungry Justice will scold when he finds none of those danties, for we both lyed abominably. Exit.

div.head: SCENE II.
div.stage: Enter Toby, and speaks to the Alderman as he returns from the door.

sp.speaker: Tob.
sp.p: Sir, I suppose you may be Mr. Alderman Furr.

sp.speaker: Fur.
sp.p: Furr is my name, your business friend.

sp.speaker: Toby.
sp.p: My Master, Sir Barnaby Buffler greets you; he sent me before to wait your coming, and to let you know, he will in few hours hence be in Town.— the farther particulars of his mind you'l understand from this— Gives him a Letter.

sp.speaker: Fur.
sp.p: I am glad he will be here to night.

sp.speaker: Toby.
sp.p: Sir, my Master's mightily pleas'd with the thoughts of Marrying your Daughter; he talks of nothing but her all day; she'l be very happy if she can but away with some small faults.

sp.speaker: Fur.
sp.p: I have taught her Obedience, and she that is so to a Father, will be the same to a Husband.— He's Rich.

sp.speaker: Tob.
sp.p: Right Sir, now I have delivered you your Letter, I'll observe my Orders, and give this to your Daughter.

sp.speaker: Fur.
sp.p: I'll send her to you, whil'st I read my Letter. Jacinta. Ex. Fur.

sp.speaker: Tob.
sp.p: Strange humour in Parents, to enslave their Children for wealth.— The estate and not the Man is now regarded.

sp.speaker: Jac.
sp.p: Pray thee, cousen, leave me not in this extremity.

sp.speaker: Hil.
sp.p: No, no, come, where is the Esquire to this Knight Errant.

sp.speaker: Tob.
sp.p: By me, Sir Barnaby Buffler commends this to the fair hands of Madam Jacinta. Jacinta takes the Letter.

sp.speaker: Jac.
sp.p: Are you his Servant.

sp.speaker: Tob.
sp.p: I am faithful Servant to your humble Servant, and the Person designed for your Husband, he desires all things may be in readiness to night, that the Marriage may be solemnized to Morrow morning.

sp.speaker: Jac.
sp.p: His message seems to imply a command.

sp.speaker: Tob.
sp.p: He's a Person not to be thwarted nor instructed, for when he has once sayd the word— hum.— To Jacinta.

sp.speaker: Hil.
sp.p:
This Buffler's but a foolish kind of a name, come friend, be frank with us, and let us know a little more of his humour, To Toby.
— but first what manner of person is he?

sp.speaker: Tob.
sp.p: Auh, a Spark of the times; a brisk blade of a about Fifty five Years of Age, who to cool the intemperance of his Youth,— resolves forthwith to take the Sovereign Remedy, a Wife.

sp.speaker: Hil.
sp.p: Make hast and let us see the Letter, for if he be a lover of that Age, his stile must be very amourous and pleasant; for nothing's more ridiculous than an old Batchelor in Love, or to set up for a Beau.

sp.speaker: Tob.
sp.p: You'll find it a very extraordinary Letter.

sp.speaker: Jac.
sp.p: Did he read it to you.

sp.speaker: Tob.
sp.p: With a very cheerful countenance.

sp.speaker: Hil.
sp.p: Since he is his Confident, read it out.

body.p: MY Child, I have an Estate in two Counties, I am Lord of three Manners, I have One Thousand Five Hundred Thirty Six Pounds Thirteen Shillings and Four pence Half penny Rent, besides Pepper Corns; and Esquire Careless, my half and only Brother, is my next Heir, if I Die without Issue. I am told that in Marrying you, I may get as many Children as I think good; prepare therefore against to morrow, in order to the first; as for the rest, we'll think of them at leasure. Consider you lodge at an Inn, therefore be not seen but in a Masque, that it may not be said you appeared in publick places amongst strangers, for methinks already I begin to be concerned for your Honour, and that you ought not to be seen without my leave.

sp.speaker: Jac.
sp.p: This Knight must be some strange Monster.

sp.speaker: Hil.
sp.p: This fellow's of a Complexion to tell all. Well friend,— you say your Master is elderly, but as to his Person.

sp.speaker: Tob.
sp.p: Why, pretty bulky— but lusty and Heartwhole.

sp.speaker: Hil.
sp.p: The caution in his Letter, shows him of a Jealous humour.

sp.speaker: Tob.
sp.p: If he be jealous of his Wife, as he is of his Money, the Devil shan't get her out of his clutches.

sp.speaker: Hil.
sp.p: And obstinate.

sp.speaker: Tob
sp.p: As a Bitch that has Puppies, When you bid her come off her litter, he'll have his humour, thô the Devil stood at the door.

sp.speaker: Jac.
sp.p: And how must a Wife deal with all these good qualities.

sp.speaker: Tob.
sp.p: To tell you my mind, in short, I e'en pity you, that so handsome a young Lady should be Married to a gruf Curmudgeonly old fellow, with whom you can never enjoy a minutes happiness; in hopes to be left a rich Widdow.

sp.speaker: Hil
sp.p: You speak honestly.

sp.speaker: Jac.
sp.p: How miserable shall I be made.

sp.speaker: Fur.
sp.p: Well, have you done your Message according to order?

sp.speaker: Tob.
sp.p: I have said my say, and now I'll go acquaint my Master.

sp.speaker: Fur.
sp.p: The Bells ring to Prayers— Put your selves in order, and go to the Cathedral. By that time— your intended Husband, Sir Barnaby, will be here, at present he's busie with the Toby Exit. Attorney, to get the Writings drawn according to our agreement, that all things may be in readiness against to morrow Morning, the time prefixt for the Marriage.

sp.speaker: Jac.
sp.p: Sure, Sir, if you lov'd me, you'd not be so hasty to part with me.

sp.speaker: Fur.
sp.p: 'Tis the great care and love I have for you, makes me solicitous to see you well disposed of: There ends a Father's care, for when he gives a Daughter in marriage, 'tis suppos'd he gives her to more than a Father; for such is a Husband. Husband and Wife are one.

sp.speaker: Hil.
sp.p: That Rule, Uncle, won't hold in Arithmetick, for according to the first Principle, one and one, make two.

sp.speaker: Fur.
sp.p: Mad-Cap Niece, meddle with your own matters— Let me see—

sp.speaker: Hil.
sp.p: Nay, Uncle, ne'r put on your Considering-Cap for an Answer; what I say is true, and I'll give you a farther demonstration that Man and Wife are not one: For in this Age they are seldom or never together, the Man's in one place and the Wife in another; as far asunder as ever they can get: And you know 'tis impossible for one and the same thing, to be at the same time in several places.

sp.speaker: Fur.
sp.p: She has a very unhappy Wit; I am glad, Daughter, that you are going from her, for she's enough to spoil all the young Women she meets with▪ But I hope she'll have a Husband will meet with her.

sp.speaker: Hil.
sp.p: Never of your choosing, Uncle.

sp.speaker: Fur.
sp.p: Likely so, for you're hair-brain'd enough to do things of your own head.

sp.speaker: Hil.
sp.p: Do you think, Uncle, I han't as much Wit to choose a Husband as you?

sp.speaker: Fur.
sp.p: Well, well, follow your own course; but I hope you'll get a Husband one day will Cudgel your bones for you.

sp.speaker: Hil.
sp.p:
But, Uncle, it is not now as it was in your young days; Women, then, were poor sneaking Sheepish Creatures, but in this Age we know our own strength, and have Wit enough to make use of our
Talents: If I meet with a Husband makes my Heart ake, I'll make his Head ake.

sp.speaker: Fur.
sp.p: I am apt enough to believe, one House will be too hot to hold you long: I doubt not but your Husband (whoever shall have the ill fortune to be so) will in a short time be as weary of you as I am.

sp.speaker: Hil.
sp.p: Shou'd he prove but half so ill natur'd as you are (which certainly no young man can) I'd swear my self a Virgin, and consequently sue out a Divorce against him for impotency.

sp.speaker: Fur.
sp.p: Come, Niece, leave your unluckiness, and now I have brought you down for company, don't employ your Wit to teach my Daughter disobedience.

sp.speaker: Hil.
sp.p: These old Fornicators keep such ado with Obedience—

sp.speaker: Fur.
sp.p: Go, get you gone to Church—

sp.speaker: Hil.
sp.p: To Church, or any where, to be rid of an old man.

sp.speaker: Fur.
sp.p: Go, go, I have other business than to mind your tittle tattle.

sp.speaker: Hil.
sp.p: Farewel, Nuncle— Teach my Grannam to— Spin.

sp.speaker: Jac.
sp.p: Thou art a mad Wench to talk so. Fur Exit.

sp.speaker: Hil.
sp.p: Pish— I'd have Women say, and do what they list; Have not we rational Souls as well as men? What made Women mopes in former Ages, but being rul'd by a company of old Men and Women? Dotage then was counted Wisdom, and Formality call'd Gravity and good Behaviour.

sp.speaker: Jac.
sp.p: What would you advise me to in this extremity? I shall never love this Knight.

sp.speaker: Hil.
sp.p: Let him know your mind, and if he won't believe you he's an unmannerly Fool; And there's an end. Come Wench— Exeunt.

sp.speaker: Tob.
sp.p: O here's my Master: Sir, they are come, I have deliver'd the Letters.

sp.speaker: Lov.
sp.p: My Sister and I then will give them a visit presently; whilst she holds the Old man in discourse, I'll upbraid Jacinta.

sp.speaker: Tob.
sp.p: 'Tis sore against her will— But you'll have a better opportunity— for in my hearing the Alderman bid them go hear Prayers at the great Church, 'twill not be long ere they come this way.

sp.speaker: Lov.
sp.p: Haste then to our Inn, acquaint my Sister they are come, and tell her the occasion of my stay.— Toby Exit. Here's one not in Love— he's so merry.

sp.speaker: Carel.
sp.p: Ha! Is not that my old Friend— Franck Lovell?

sp.speaker: Lov.
sp.p: Careless!— who thought to have met you at Canterbury after eight years absence. How fares my friend?

sp.speaker: Carel.
sp.p: Well in health and mind: In Purse too, I hope.

sp.speaker: Lov.
sp.p: Where have you been all this while? What Country has held you?

sp.speaker: Carel.
sp.p: All Countries, and sometimes no Country; for I have been most of the time at Sea.

sp.speaker: Lov.
sp.p: At Sea!

sp.speaker: Carel.
sp.p: I'll tell thee in short— Coming, at the Death of my Father, to a Mortgag'd Estate, and I too extravagant to recover it, went a Voluntier to Sea, aboard one of the King's Frigats; when our Fleet return'd I went aboard the French, then the Dutch, and so from one Fleet to another, till I touch'd upon most of the known Coasts the Christian World Trafficks to. By this time I hope my Estate is disincumber'd, and I am free in the World.

sp.speaker: Lov.
sp.p: Prudently done, and now you are grown a stanch sober man.

sp.speaker: Carel.
sp.p: I have not parted with one grain of my old humour, I am as wild as ever, only I have learn'd to Sin at cheaper Rates. But what's more material, let me know what's become of thy elder Brother— Is he Dead yet, and you in possession of the whole Estate?

sp.speaker: Lov.
sp.p: No, he lives; and what is worse, now in his Old Age is going to marry.

sp.speaker: Carel.
sp.p: Bring me to him, I'll Drink him Dead.

sp.speaker: Lov.
sp.p: If the Drink were Poyson, 'twou'd scarce have time to work. To morrow is the prefix'd day, unless prevented by Stratagem: My Sister and I, by his Gracious Letters, are invited down to his Wedding.

sp.speaker: Carel.
sp.p: Lives the Lady here in Canterbury?

sp.speaker: Lov.
sp.p: At London— But he durst not venture thither for fear of Expences— and that after Marriage— his Wife shou'd be buying fine Coaches, Beds, and Furniture.

sp.speaker: Carel.
sp.p: Prudently consider'd.

sp.speaker: Lov.
sp.p: This therefore was the appointed place to meet at; her Father and he have treated by Letters this Twelve-month, but a Nights Courtship must serve the Lady: He marries her in the morning, and the next day removes to his Country House.

sp.speaker: Carel.
sp.p: Which must be her Monument— for there she'll be buried alive!— Is she likely to have Children?

sp.speaker: Lov.
sp.p: Young and handsome.

sp.speaker: Carel.
sp.p: That's bad—

sp.speaker: Lov.
sp.p: But what's worse, she's the only Woman I ever did, or can love. But my discourse is unseasonable— Let me know your Inn, I'll visit you at Night, and tell you all.

sp.speaker: Carel.
sp.p: Whither are you now going?

sp.speaker: Lov.
sp.p: The party I have been speaking of, is going to Church, and I take this opportunity to discourse her.

sp.speaker: Carel.
sp.p: 'Tis gone too far— Let thy dull Elder Brother take her, you shall along with me— I'll show you a Companion worth forty Mistresses.

sp.speaker: Lov.
sp.p: What is he?

sp.speaker: Carel.
sp.p: An honest Tarpaulin— The Son of an English Renegade: He was born a Ship-board, and never was ashore beyond a Sea Port Town— except up in the Countries amongst Indians and Spaniards, to Ravage, Burn, and Plunder, for he has been a Buccanier from his Infancy.

sp.speaker: Lov.
sp.p: His Employment disgraces not his Parentage.

sp.speaker: Carel.
sp.p: Stout he is and brave— and that temper has inclin'd him to leave that hellish Crew, and employ his Valour in the Service of his Father's Native Country: He brings with him sixty thousand Crowns, and doubtless will have good Employment— for from Captains of Ships, and Governors of Plantations, the King has heard much of his Valour— Come, you shall drink a Bottle, or a Bowl of Punch, with me and the Captain.

sp.speaker: Lov.
sp.p: Were I going to any one but a Mistress.

sp.speaker: Carel.
sp.p: Pox o'thy Mistress; if thou wert going to a Wench I might excuse you— but I should think my self curs'd, should I consent thou shouldst solicit any Woman in the way of Matrimony.

sp.speaker: Lov.
sp.p: Will you never leave this lewd wild humour?

sp.speaker: Carel.
sp.p: Not upon the score of Matrimony. Why, Franck, I'll tell thee, I am now like a Calf in the Fens, that straggles every where, and feeds where I like best; but should I marry, I shou'd be tether'd to one spot of Ground; at best, be confin'd to an Enclosure.

sp.speaker: Lov.
sp.p: The Horse that is loose often falls into a foul Ditch, or is put in the Pound for straying in his Neighbours Ground: Marriage is honorable and safe.

sp.speaker: Carel.
sp.p: It wou'd be so if all Wives were honest: I'll undertake a Mistress shall love thee twice as long as any Wife thou can'st find. Nothing choaks Love like the Surety of Possession: Love is an excellent Meat, but Marriage an ill Sauce. Were I going to Tyburn, I wou'd cry, drive on Carman, and choose to Sing a Penitential Psalm at the Gallows, rather than return to say, For Better for Worse.

sp.speaker: Lov.
sp.p: Atheists in Love, like Zealots in Religion, are not to be reclaimed by Argument, yet now and then are converted by some lucky accident, you may one day see a beauty, that like a burning glass shall draw all thy loose flames within a narrow compass.

sp.speaker: Carl.
sp.p: Beauty is more brittle than the glass you talk of, and Man's estimation of it less durable. I may perchance Love only one at once; but not that one always; and whilst I am in my right wits, I will not leave delightful variety, for the unsavory insipid bitts of Constancy.

sp.speaker: Lov.
sp.p: Well, Jacinta has a Kinswoman for her Companion, so beautiful, her Eyes would fix your wandering thoughts, and make you abandon all Women for her sake.

sp.speaker: Carl.
sp.p: So thinks the devout young Novice, newly enter'd into his Cloisture; he has no sooner forsaken the World, the Flesh, and the Devil, but imagines he is able to make the greatest Debauchée, in Love with Mortification.

sp.speaker: Lov.
sp.p: My mind at present is not composed enough, to return an answer to every thing you urge; but venter your self with me into her company, and if ever you return the same Man—

sp.speaker: Carl.
sp.p: I know my self so well grounded in Sin, and have tasted so much the sweets of wickedness, that I dare venter my self into any temptation to the contrary; and to see this miracle, will suffer my self to be seduc'd into civil company, and if they do debauch me—

sp.speaker: Lov.
sp.p: Come then.

sp.speaker: Tob.
sp.p: Sir, Madam, Jacinta and her Cousen went out the back way, but I believe Prayers were almost done,— for they return already.— See yonder, they come with their Masks on. I know their Petticoats.

sp.speaker: Lov.
sp.p: Retire— whilst I discourse one, do you detain the other, to give me opportunity; these are they—

sp.speaker: Carl.
sp.p: Accost thy own natural, and leave me to manage the other impertinent.

sp.speaker: Lov.
sp.p: My Heart's my guide,— stay Jacinta, take off your mask, and let me see if your Face is as much alter'd as your Heart. Do you fly me,— but I'll persue you, as Jac. Lov. Exeunt. a Ghost does the guilty Murderer.

sp.speaker: Carl.
sp.p: If you have lost your Tongue too, ye are a blessed pair,— so were it not for your Tongues, you Women would all be Angels▪

sp.speaker: Hil.
sp.p: Da-da— da— Hil. strives to run out by him.

sp.speaker: Carl.
sp.p: Nay, nay, you are not to pass so, I am resolv'd both to hear and see you first.

sp.speaker: Hil.
sp.p: Well, what would the Man be at?

sp.speaker: Carl.
sp.p: The Man's at what he would be, he's at you.

sp.speaker: Hil.
sp.p: What do you mean?

sp.speaker: Carl.
sp.p: Faith I can't resolve you till I see your Face; pull off your Mask, and then I'll tell you what I mean.

sp.speaker: Hil.
sp.p: Suppose I won't.

sp.speaker: Carl,
sp.p: Than I shall suppose you very ugly,— for I never knew a Woman that had a handsome Face, could endure to hide it.

sp.speaker: Hil.
sp.p: Yes, if she likes not her Company.

sp.speaker: Carl.
sp.p: Yet she'd have her company like her; I trust more to a Woman's pride, than her Love or good Nature; for thô they are ugly, they think themselves handsome, and wou'd be thought so by others.

sp.speaker: Hil.
sp.p: Why then do they maintain the humour of Vizard Masks?

sp.speaker: Carl.
sp.p: Because under them they Sin conceal'd. I'll avouch, Vizard Masks ruin more Women's Virtues, than all the Bawds in the Nation.

sp.speaker: Hil.
sp.p: Your Reason for that, good Mr. Voucher.

sp.speaker: Carl.
sp.p: Under the vizard, the Wife goes to the Play, Ball, or Masquerade, undiscovered to her Husband; the Maid unknown to her Mistress; the Daughter or Neice, unperceived by her Relations; the Mask draws the Gallants, and thô at first you come but out of curiosity, to hear what Men will say, our quick Repartees, our gentle Bawdry, and brisk raillery, tickles your Ears; your bodies are Buxome, your Bloods grow wanton, your fancy strikes firmly on some Man or other, the Gallant grows importunate, and you are Conquer'd.

sp.speaker: Hil.
sp.p: Do you find them so frail?

sp.speaker: Carl.
sp.p: A Woman's Ear is the Outwork to her Chastity, lodge your self but there, and the Fort is more than half taken; when once a Woman hearkens to what you say, she'll soon do what you'd have her.

sp.speaker: Hil.
sp.p: Then you take a Parley for a Surrender.

sp.speaker: Carl.
sp.p: No, but after a Parley they soon yield.

sp.speaker: Hil.
sp.p: Now I have a mind to stay and talk with you, but must be forc'd to leave you, to avoid your ill Opinion.

sp.speaker: Carl.
sp.p: Nay, if you have a mind to't, you'll do't, let me think what I will; and if you won't pull off your Mask, I'll e'en begon and leave you— fare you well.

sp.speaker: Hil.
sp.p: And fare you well. Turn from each other, and look back o'er their Shoulders.

sp.speaker: Carl.
sp.p: Nay, if you look o're the Shoulder at me, I'll turn again, for you have no mind I should begon, I'm sure.

sp.speaker: Hil.
sp.p: Why did you look back at me?

sp.speaker: Carl.
sp.p: To see—

sp.speaker: Hil.
sp.p: If I would look at you, and so we e'en caught one another; and what can you say to me, that I can't retort on you again.

sp.speaker: Carl.
sp.p: But I'll be judg'd by your self, if I have not more Reason to think you desire my stay, than I yours; you have a full sight of me, see what I am, and know whither you like me or not; you are all Vizard, Scarf, and Petticoat; for ought I know, you may want a Nose, set of Teeth, be Squint-Ey'd, or blobber Lip'd.

sp.speaker: Hil.
sp.p: You'l make me as ugly as the Devil, am I not cloven footed, think you?

sp.speaker: Carl.
sp.p: I'll tell you that presently. Offers to look at her legs.

sp.speaker: Hil.
sp.p: Nay,—

sp.speaker: Carl.
sp.p: A handsome Leg and Foot, I'll be sworn; and here's a well shap'd Hand and Arm, and what Breasts are here, how round and plump.

sp.speaker: Hil.
sp.p: Hands off, your enquiry begins to grow troublesome.

sp.speaker: Carl.
sp.p: If you have a Face and Features, answerable to your Limbs, y'are a prime piece of Woman's flesh.

sp.speaker: Hil.
sp.p: Do you think I have?

sp.speaker: Carl.
sp.p: Gad do I.

sp.speaker: Hil.
sp.p: Than to keep your good Opinion, I'll be gone, and you shan't see't. Nay, nay, no attempts— hands off. Offers to pull of her Mask.

sp.speaker: Carl.
sp.p: I have sworn to see't.

sp.speaker: Hil.
sp.p: And I have sworn you shall, but stand at greater distance, farther, farther yet, see— Hil. gets her back close to the door, pulls of her Mask, and runs off.

sp.speaker: Carl.
sp.p: Excellent Creature!

sp.speaker: Hil.
sp.p: Fare you well.

sp.speaker: Carl.
sp.p: Ha, are you so cunning; she's gone. by her wit I did not think she had had so good a Face; for wit and beauty seldom go together, in a Woman, she has a large stock of both, and I could wish my self in Bed with her; but the thoughts of her are momentary.

sp.speaker: Lov.
sp.p: False, faithless Woman.

sp.speaker: Carl.
sp.p: Prythee think no more of her, come now go with me and be merry, we'll have Women in abundance.

sp.speaker: Lov.
sp.p: Hang 'em Jilts.

sp.speaker: Carl.
sp.p:
No, such Women as your Mistriss is, are more like Jilts, those I mean are good Conscionable Girls, that will not let you spend your
Money for nothing, with the others you wast your Gold and time, and at last like young Heifers, when they come to be milk'd, spurn at you in defiance, and away they frisk.

sp.speaker: Lov.
sp.p: Ah Jacinta; can a Father's word outweigh a Lover's vows.

sp.speaker: Carl.
sp.p: Damn this pining, whining, puling, peaking, sneaking, sniveling Love; I'll carry you where you shall see, merry, gay, jocond, sprightly Love; thou shalt have it in Armfuls, and dilate thy self in pleasure.

sp.speaker: Lov.
sp.p: I shall be no company, my Soul is out of tune.

sp.speaker: Carl.
sp.p: We'll have Musick, Wine, and Women, to divert you: yet in spight of all the Sex,

lg.l: I'll keep my Soul free, as the Bird that flies i'th' Air,
And ne'er Love one, till I of all the rest despair.

div.head: SCENE I.
div.stage: Enter Hilaria, Jacinta, and Careless on the other side the stage.

sp.speaker: Hil.
sp.p: 'TIS a fine Evening, Cousen, and I love to look about me.

sp.speaker: Carl.
sp.p: Ha! these are they.

sp.speaker: Jac.
sp.p: Here comes Mr. Lovel's Friend.

sp.speaker: Hil.
sp.p: We'll stand him bare fac'd.

sp.speaker: Carl.
sp.p: Now, which is she that I am in Love with?

sp.speaker: Jac.
sp.p: He's at a stand.

sp.speaker: Hil.
sp.p: He'd fain know me again; but prithee take up a brisk humour, and let's try to puzle him.

sp.speaker: Jac.
sp.p: No, prithee let's go in.

sp.speaker: Carl.
sp.p: What are you upon the Wing, or do you come out a grazing like Rabbits, just at the Burrow's mouth; that as soon as any body comes, you may pop into your holes again.

sp.speaker: Hil.
sp.p: We had need be watchful, when such pochers as you are abroad.

sp.speaker: Carl.
sp.p: Your Watchfulness signifies little; I come now like a Ferret to creep into your holes, and scare you out of your Burrows.

sp.speaker: Jac.
sp.p: But if instead of a Burrow, you should run into a Warrenner's trap.

sp.speaker: Hil.
sp.p: And that you may easily do, for we are no out-lying Conies, we keep within heart of the Warren.

sp.speaker: Carl.
sp.p:
Ay, but I know your Musees, your inlets and outlets, and wherever the Rabbits pass, the Ferret or Weesel may venter. You see
I come just to the same place; 'twas here you popt in from me before; But now I am got between you and the hedge.

sp.speaker: Jac.
sp.p: But how do you know, that we are the same pair?

sp.speaker: Hil.
sp.p: And which of us is it, that was too nimble for you?

sp.speaker: Jac.
sp.p: You had best have a care on which you venter, for in such cases, you ought not to spoyl your friend's game.

sp.speaker: Carl.
sp.p: 'Tis one of you.

sp.speaker: Hil.
sp.p: I see you are no good hound; you can't follow the scent well.

sp.speaker: Carl.
sp.p: Many a good nos'd Dog is at a loss, when the scent is cross'd; but if I catch one, and my friend the other; if we are mistaken, let him say which is his, and we'l make a change.

sp.speaker: Jac.
sp.p: But which of us two do you think would fall to your share?

sp.speaker: Carl.
sp.p: Y'Gad I don't know.

sp.speaker: Hil.
sp.p: Don't you know a Woman's Face, when you see't a second time?

sp.speaker: Carl.
sp.p: She show'd it with such a Legerde-main— her Mask was no sooner of, then on again, and she was gone.

sp.speaker: Jac.
sp.p: Observe us well.

sp.speaker: Carl.
sp.p: Let me see— Faith not I,— if you had your Masks on, I should know her from a Thousand, at the very sight of her Vizard, my Heart would go pit— a— pat.

sp.speaker: Hil.
sp.p: If you are so in Love with the complexion of Velvet, you should have a Negro for your Mistress.

sp.speaker: Carl.
sp.p: There is beauty in black, why else do Ladies put on patches, and some love black Hair better than light, and why not black Faces as well.

sp.speaker: Jac.
sp.p: But you'd be for a white one at this time, if you knew which was under the Vizard you like so well.

sp.speaker: Hil,
sp.p: I am glad he does not, for than he'd pretend Love to one of us.

sp.speaker: Carl.
sp.p: Gad but I wou'd not to you, nor e'er a Woman in the World.

sp.speaker: Jac.
sp.p: I dare swear you wou'd.

sp.speaker: Carl.
sp.p: Perhaps I might make you believe I was in Love with you.

sp.speaker: Jac.
sp.p: No, that you cou'd ne'er do.

sp.speaker: Carl.
sp.p: Why, don't you think your selves handsome enough to be lov'd.

sp.speaker: Jac.
sp.p: Yes; but we think you have more Wit.

sp.speaker: Carl.
sp.p: What, than to Love one of you?

sp.speaker: Hil.
sp.p: Yes, or any body else, that is ne'er like to Love again.

sp.speaker: Carl.
sp.p: Are you an Enemy to me, or to Love?

sp.speaker: Hil.
sp.p: To Love; I think it a very foolish thing.

sp.speaker: Carl.
sp.p: But 'tis Marriage makes it so, give me Love as nature made it, free and unconfin'd— observe but Mistriss and Gallant, how brisk, how gay, how fierce they are in their Amours! whilst Marriage-Love comes like a Slave, loaden with Fetters, dull and out of humour.

sp.speaker: Hil.
sp.p: For my part, I am rather for a Gallant, than a Husband.

sp.speaker: Jac.
sp.p: So am I clearly—

sp.speaker: Carl.
sp.p: 'Tis well dissembled on one side; one of you I am sure speaks against her Conscience; but if you are as you say, y'are Girls for me.

sp.speaker: Jac.
sp.p: What both—

sp.speaker: Carl.
sp.p: Both, I gad both.

sp.speaker: Hil.
sp.p: Hold, one's enough, and if you'll be a Gallant to one of us, we expect you shou'd be constant.

sp.speaker: Carl.
sp.p: That circumstance makes it too like Marriage.

sp.speaker: Hil.
sp.p: The constancy is while you pretend; not but that either Mistresses or Gallant may choose elsewhere, but they must love but one at once

sp.speaker: Jac.
sp.p: But which of us will you choose?

sp.speaker: Carl.
sp.p: Faith I'll be for her I talk'd to in the Mask.

sp.speaker: Hil.
sp.p: Well Sir, when you find which of us two is she; claim her for your Mistress.

sp.speaker: Carl.
sp.p: Adieu.

sp.speaker: Hil.
sp.p: Come Hilaria. Ex. Jac. Hil

sp.speaker: Carl.
sp.p: Ha Hilaria! I faith that's she, but they are gone in; Jacinta I remember is the name of Lovel's Mistress; till now I fanci'd the other was she, because more brisk and airy. Well I'll find out Lovel, and we'll give 'em a visit.

div.head: SCENE II.
div.stage: Enter Justice Greedy, and First Innkeeper. Greedy, with a Cane striking.

sp.speaker: Greed.
sp.p: Sirrah; Dog.

sp.speaker: 1 Inn.
sp.p: Sir, I beseech you.

sp.speaker: Greed.
sp.p: Rogue, I'll break your bones.

sp.speaker: 1 Inn.
sp.p: Mr. Justice, Sir, and please your worship,— do but hear me.

sp.speaker: Greed.
sp.p: I cannot hear of Mercy, Hunger cries lowder against thee for Vengeance.

sp.speaker: 2 Inn.
sp.p: Have moderation Sir, in your Anger,— Justice has a scale for Mercy, as well as Rigor.

sp.speaker: Greed.
sp.p: Do'st thou see villanous Host, I am so weak and faint for want of Eating, I can hardly follow thee.

sp.speaker: 1 Inn.
sp.p: Sir, on my word you shall have an excellent Supper.

sp.speaker: Greed.
sp.p: But disappointment Sirrah,— didst not thou prate to me of Bruges Capons, Marrow puddings, and—

sp.speaker: 1 Inn.
sp.p:
That was only and please your Worship to out-lie my Neighbour,
he had no Gaunt Veal, and please your Worship— nor—

sp.speaker: Greed.
sp.p: O I shall go into a Consumption, Sirrah! my fancy has mounted Constellation height,— I supped Jelly from the Stars in conceit, and now must I be content with dry Mutton and Rabbit?—

sp.speaker: 1 Inn.
sp.p: I'll make amends to Morrow, Sir, at the Wedding Dinner, I'll send Man and Horse round the Country to pick up dainties.

sp.speaker: Greed.
sp.p: But I have longings, Sirrah, I have longings more dangerous than a Womans with Child. O! I have wamblings in my Stomach.

sp.speaker: 1 Inn.
sp.p: What thinks your Worship of a glass of Canary,— I have a Flower.

sp.speaker: Gree.
sp.p: Do, do, bring't, or I shall faint.

sp.speaker: 1 Inn.
sp.p: And to enable you till Supper, a slice of potted Venison.

sp.speaker: Greed.
sp.p: Ay, ay, for I am like a Mud Wall falling to decay; I want patching up. 1 Inn. Exit

div.head: SCENE III.

sp.speaker: Fur.
sp.p: Mr. Justice, whilst I have leasure, let me desire the favour of you, to take the care of providing and ordering a handsome entertainment against to morrow. Spare for no cost.

sp.speaker: Greed.
sp.p: That's well, that's well.

sp.speaker: Fur.
sp.p: Let every thing be in the best manner, I leave it wholy and solely to you.

sp.speaker: Greed.
sp.p: Both as to quantity,— quality,— manner, ordering, dressing, and every thing?

sp.speaker: Fur.
sp.p: Every thing!—

sp.speaker: Greed.
sp.p: Without Molestation,— Contradiction,— or controul?

sp.speaker: Fur.
sp.p: Absolutely and entirely.

sp.speaker: Greed.
sp.p: I love to understand the extent of my Commission, now am I Lord over the Boyl'd,— Bak'd, and Roast.

div.stage: Re-enter Innkeeper. With a Bottle and a Plate.

sp.speaker: 1 Inn.
sp.p: Mr. Justice, please you to taste?

sp.speaker: Greed.
sp.p: Mr. Alderman, my service to you; special Drinks and Eats. Canary, ha! this Venison has a good smack with't. Ay, this is a fit relish to recover a balk'd Stomach.

sp.speaker: Jane.
sp.p: Sir, here's some Gentlemen and a Lady enquire for you.

sp.speaker: Fur.
sp.p: Oh our Friends are come! Show 'em in, and call down my Daughter. Ex. Jane.

div.head: SCENE IV.
div.stage: Enter to them, Sir Barnaby Buffler, Mr. Lovel, and Dashwel, with a black Box, and a Rowl of Parchment under his Arm, with Pen and Ink, hanging at his Girdle, and Arabella after.—

sp.speaker: Sir Bar.
sp.p: I thank you Mr. Alderman, A good welcome is the best Dish at a Feast. This is my half Brother, and this our Sister.

sp.speaker: Fur.
sp.p: Sir your Servant— Madam give me leave— All salute each other.

sp.speaker: Greed.
sp.p: Your Servant Sir, Sir your Servant, Madam your humble Servant. (Greed. speaks with his Mouth'full, and wipes it with the back of his Hand to salute Arabella.)

sp.speaker: Fur.
sp.p: Here's my Daughter, Sir Barnaby bids you welcome.

sp.speaker: Sir Bar.
sp.p: He comes well that comes to a good end,— Lady, your humble Servant, and faithful Husband, till death us part.

sp.speaker: Jac.
sp.p: Your Servant Sir.

sp.speaker: Sir. Bar.
sp.p: And now Father-in-Law— thô I never saw you before, yet we understand one another by letters,— therefore let's fall to the matter, and spare complements.

sp.speaker: Fur.
sp.p: Ay, Sir Barnaby, no matter for ceremony amongst Friends.

sp.speaker: Sir Bar.
sp.p: No, for Ceremony, is the Wiseman's scorn, the Fools delight, and the Idleman's business.

sp.speaker: Fur.
sp.p: Ay, Sir Barnaby, I am for down right dealing—

sp.speaker: Sir. Bar.
sp.p: That's best,— for Full of Curtisy, full of Craft— and fair words won't fill a Bushel. Here then is the mark I shoot at, I come to Marry your Daughter.

sp.speaker: Fur.
sp.p: Right—

sp.speaker: Sir Bar.
sp.p: You and I understand one the other, and Marriage Articles are agreed on betwixt us.

sp.speaker: Fur.
sp.p: Right— I writ you my mind to every particular.

sp.speaker: Sir Bar.
sp.p: Now Sir, knowing that Forecast is as good as Work, I have brought the Marriage writings ready drawn, and my Attorney to see 'em sign'd and seal'd, come hither Dash—

sp.speaker: Dash.
sp.p: Here and please your Worship's are the Deeds that concern your Estate, and here the Marriage, Settlement, and Joynters, and so forth.

sp.speaker: Fur.
sp.p: Very well Sir Barnaby.

sp.speaker: Sir Bar.
sp.p:
This I did to prevent expences, for 'tis chargeable lying at Inns— A penny sav'd, is a penny got. And I have brought my Brother and Sister, that being altogether, we may be so much the
cheaper.

sp.speaker: Fur.
sp.p: They are welcome Guests,— spare for nothing that the place affords.

sp.speaker: Sir Bar.
sp.p: I Love to Be merry and wise. Enough's as good as a Feast. And now Sir, whilst you peruse the Writings, I'll open my mind to your Daughter; we shall soon have done— Few words are best amongst Friends.

sp.speaker: Fur.
sp.p: We'll withdraw into a another Room, and leave you to your selves. Come Gentlemen.

sp.speaker: Greed.
sp.p: Look you after Joynters and Settlements— I'll into my Kingdom, and take possession of my new Office. I come ye Woodcocks, Pheasants, Patridges, and Quales: O ye darlings of Nature, ye tempters of the Appetite, I am coming amongst you, to hug kiss and embrace your beautiful limbs.

sp.speaker: Sir Bar.
sp.p: Who does he mean?

sp.speaker: Greed.
sp.p: I could e'en jump out of my Skin for joy; now will I Eat often, and give thanks when my Belly's full: For I could never remember to say Grace before Meat, in my Life.

sp.speaker: Sir Bar.
sp.p: What say you Sir—

sp.speaker: Greed.
sp.p: Say— why I say Sir, Store is no Sore; and that's a better say, than Your enough's as good as a Feast. Chew upon that Sir Barnaby, till I come again.— Greed. Ex.

div.head: SCENE V.
div.stage: Enter Sir Barnaby, and Mrs. Jacinta.

sp.speaker: Sir Bar.
sp.p: This is some prodigal Glutton, I wonder Mr. Alderman will keep him company— One scabby Sheep is enough to infect a whole Flock. But not to stand thruming of Caps, my Wife that is to be— I am now to tell you, that since your Father and I are agreed, there only remains, that I open my breast to you in these particulars. First, as to my Person, you see it well enough, there's nothing to be disliked; nature has been sufficiently bountiful to me, I am As strait as an Arrow; as plump as a Patridge;— and as sound as a Roach. But it may be said, I am of a full Age;— the better for you. Better be an Old Man's darling, than a Young Man's warling. And he that Marries e'er he be wise, shall Die e'er he thrive. Now I found in my self an inclination to like you, the first and only time I saw you— which was last Year, when you were with your Uncle in our Country, at the Sheriffs Feast. I don't say you took notice of me.

sp.speaker: Jac.
sp.p: No indeed Sir—

sp.speaker: Sir Bar.
sp.p:
Hold, I don't ask you questions— because I would not
give you the trouble of answering. Now as I had a liking to you at first sight— So I know you must have some inclination in nature, to think well of me for a Husband. For I observe your Eye has been upon me e'er since I came— Looking breeds liking; and Where the Eye fixes, the Heart soon follows. So there's an end of that. Secondly, I am none of those that mind Fashions— Wisemen invent Fashions, and Fools follow 'em. I am rather for saving than spending, ever keeping in mind, that, To save is Healthful, to get is Comfortable, but to spend is Intolerable. Now my taking you for a Wife, shows what good Opinion I have of you, and that I believe you to be prudent enough, to imitate so reasonable a Husband; for without that and your Father's Three Thousand Pound, (which I would have with you) I shou'd never have Marryed you— nor can I doubt you hereafter, since A good Jack makes a good Jill. And from the moment I Marry you, I'll make you Mistress of all I am worth, (upon condition) you lay not any of it out, upon any occasion whatsoever.

sp.speaker: Jac.
sp.p: How Sir, not—

sp.speaker: Sir Bar.
sp.p: Hold again— Marriage brings the Key that unlocks a Virgin's Mouth. Maids must be seen, not heard. Lastly, to discover my whole Heart to you, because Children are certain Cares, but uncertain Comforts; and because they will cost a great deal bringing up, and moreover for that I love you so tenderly, we will get but one or two at most, and than I will forbear making you afraid, lest you should Die in Childbed, For the Pitcher goes not so often to the Well, but it comes home broken at last. Thus having told you all that's necessary, and finding you so reasonable, and we both so well agreed. I'll instantly acquaint your Father,— put all things in readiness to Night, be Marryed in the Morning according to the Old Rule,— Happy is the Wooing, that is not long a doing. Adieu Wife.

sp.speaker: Jac.
sp.p: Two words to a bargain, the Proverb says; but he'll not allow me one.

sp.speaker: Hil.
sp.p: Cozen, I heard all your Courtship; you have a most Sententious Lover. You'll be married to the whole Book of Proverbs.

sp.speaker: Jac.
sp.p: He would not let me speak a word, but is gone away with all the presumption imaginable that I love him.

sp.speaker: Hil.
sp.p: 'Tis a strange Devil.

sp.speaker: Jac.
sp.p: Which way shall I divert this ridiculous marriage? My Father will hearken to nothing I can say.

div.head: SCENE VII.
div.stage: Enter to them Lovell and Careless.

sp.speaker: Hil.
sp.p: Here's Mr. Lovell, he's the fittest person for you to consult with— O Gallant! who sent for you? To Careless.

sp.speaker: Carel.
sp.p: I hope, Madam, you'll allow a man to look after his heart when 'tis gone astray.

sp.speaker: Hil.
sp.p: You cou'd not find it when you saw us last.

sp.speaker: Carel.
sp.p: You conspir'd to juggle me out on't; but I know well enough which of you had it.

sp.speaker: Hil.
sp.p: You are beholden to Mr. Lovell for your knowledge.

sp.speaker: Lov.
sp.p: No, upon my word, Madam: But he has told me his last Adventure.

sp.speaker: Carel.
sp.p: Well, Madam, I hope you'll stand to your Bargain.

sp.speaker: Jac.
sp.p: We are no Flinchers; we'll not be worse than our words.

sp.speaker: Carel.
sp.p: Then I challenge you for my Mistress; you were the Lady I talk'd to in the Mask. Careless takes Jacinta by the hand.

sp.speaker: Jac.
sp.p: I am not her I assure you.

sp.speaker: Carel.
sp.p: I am well assur'd it cou'd be none but you; I knew it when I was here before, tho' I did not then own it.

sp.speaker: Jac.
sp.p: Take my word, Sir.

sp.speaker: Carel.
sp.p: Lord, that you shou'd think to deceive me! Why, all the while I was last in your company, my heart beat all on that side you stood, and my cheek next you burnt and glow'd—

sp.speaker: Hil.
sp.p: Ha, ha; 'slise, he has not found it out yet—

sp.speaker: Carel.
sp.p: Ha—

sp.speaker: Lov.
sp.p: No, I'll be sworn Careless han't you.

sp.speaker: Carel.
sp.p: I'll be sworn, Madam, Hilaria was the person.—

sp.speaker: Hil.
sp.p: Ha, ha, ha— but that's my Cozen Jacinta.

sp.speaker: Carel.
sp.p: No, no, no; did not you call her Hilaria as you went in?

sp.speaker: Hil. & Jac.
sp.p: Ha, ha, ha.

sp.speaker: Hil.
sp.p: I thought how well you knew, and therefore call'd her by my own Name on purpose to try you.

sp.speaker: Carel.
sp.p: Ba!—

sp.speaker: Lov.
sp.p: Now Careless you are caught—

sp.speaker: Carel.
sp.p: I must be impudent— Well, Madam, to let you see that I did, go both of you out of the Room, and come in Mask'd; and if I don't choose the right, I'll be content to resign the hopes of a Mistress.

sp.speaker: Jac.
sp.p: There is but right and wrong.

sp.speaker: Carel.
sp.p: To give you a greater proof on't, I'll make my choice blindfold.

sp.speaker: Hil.
sp.p: 'Twill still be an even Wager that you hit on the right.

sp.speaker: Lov.
sp.p: Careless, you are out-witted i'faith.

sp.speaker: Hil.
sp.p: Servant, our Covenant is void for Non-performance of the conditions.

sp.speaker: Carel.
sp.p: But calling me Servant, after the condition is broken, tis a confirmation— and will make it stand good in Law.

sp.speaker: Lov.
sp.p: No, Careless, that Quirk won't do.

sp.speaker: Carel.
sp.p: But, Madam, I hope you'll give a man leave to retract when he finds his Error; your self occasioned the mistake, 'twas an error of my Hand, not of my Heart, for at the same time I told you Hilaria was she, and you are Hilaria; therefore 'twas you I meant.

sp.speaker: Hil.
sp.p: Yes, yes, 'twas me you meant, when your Cheek glow'd, and your Heart beat on the left side.

sp.speaker: Hil. & Jac.
sp.p: Ha, ha, ha— Cozen, you are too great a Tyrant.
You persue your Victory too severely; 'tis Generous to give the vanquish'd Quarter.

sp.speaker: Hil.
sp.p: I do more, I give him liberty to make his Retreat.

sp.speaker: Fur.
sp.p: Mr. Lovell, they want your company within— to witness the Writings. Daughter, you must go too.

sp.speaker: Lov.
sp.p: I'll wait on you again presently. Exeunt Lovell and Jacinta.

sp.speaker: Fur.
sp.p: Sir, as you are Mr. Lovell's friend— please to Sup with us, you shall be welcome.

sp.speaker: Carel.
sp.p: Sir, I know not whither you'll tell me so when you know my business.

sp.speaker: Fur.
sp.p: Pray, what may it be?

sp.speaker: Carel.
sp.p: It was my fortune this Evening to have a sight of your Niece, as she went abroad.

sp.speaker: Hil.
sp.p: What's he going to say?

sp.speaker: Carel.
sp.p: To whom, Sir, I took so great a liking, that I cou'd not rest satisfy'd till I had found who she was; which I had no sooner done by Mr. Lovell, but engag'd him to bring me here to ask your consent to make my addresses to this fair Lady.

sp.speaker: Hil.
sp.p: O, I thought he would a been a second Sir Barnaby, and ask'd no bodies leave but his.

sp.speaker: Fur.
sp.p: Pray, who are you, Sir?

sp.speaker: Lov.
sp.p: Did you not know Colonel Careless?

sp.speaker: Fur.
sp.p: Very well— he dy'd some ten years since.

sp.speaker: Carel.
sp.p: He was my Father.

sp.speaker: Fur.
sp.p: Indeed! He left, I think, some twelve hundred a year; but incumber'd.

sp.speaker: Carel.
sp.p: He did so.

sp.speaker: Fur.
sp.p: And have you that Estate still?

sp.speaker: Carel.
sp.p: Every Acre, Sir— and the Mortgage paid off.

sp.speaker: Fur.
sp.p: I heard you were very wild.

sp.speaker: Carel.
sp.p: I have had my Frolicks, but keep my Estate out of the Devil's Clutches.

sp.speaker: Fur.
sp.p: Nay, if you were as wild as wild cou'd be, you'd meet with your Match there; My Niece is as wild as you can be, she's vain, idle, careless and talkative.

sp.speaker: Hil.
sp.p: Uncle, you shou'd do in driving a Bargain for marriage, as in selling of Horses; tell their good qualities, and leave it to them to find the ill.

sp.speaker: Fur.
sp.p: These are faults will be discovered in you at first sight.

sp.speaker: Hil.
sp.p: Sir, I hope you'll like me ne'r the worse for what he says.

sp.speaker: Fur.
sp.p: Instead of his getting you for a wife, you intend to get him for a Husband.

sp.speaker: Hil.
sp.p: It is more to the humour of the Age; if you won't commend me, I'll commend my self: And if I thought but half so well of him, as I do of my self, we'd soon shake hands, to Have and to Hold, without your leave.

sp.speaker: Fur.
sp.p: You see her humour, Sir; if after this you dare venture on her, I shall not Counsel her against you, provided you make out that Estate, for I wish her well married.

sp.speaker: Hil.
sp.p: Stay, Uncle: Now I think on't, you may take him with you, marriage is quite out of fashion, and I hate to be out on't as much as you do to be in't; if he had ten or twelve thousand a year, wou'd keep me a Coach and Six, and all things suitable to that Grandeur, I might admit him as a Gallant; and all that.

sp.speaker: Fur.
sp.p: I'll leave you to her; for at this mad rate she talks all the year round.

sp.speaker: Hil.
sp.p: Now the jest wou'd be, if you shou'd play such a simple trick to fall in Love with me indeed, and indeed. Exit Fur.

sp.speaker: Carel.
sp.p: Make your own words true, and accept me for a Gallant, I know not what may follow—.

sp.speaker: Hil.
sp.p: I'll push on the frolick at a venture, to see how far 'twill go; there's my hand to kiss, and I confer on you the Title of Servant.

sp.speaker: Carel.
sp.p: So, here's one hopeful young man in a fair way to be ruin'd.

div.head: SCENE IX.
div.stage: Enter Jacinta, Arabella, together; Lovell and Durzo after.

sp.speaker: Jac.
sp.p: To morow I shall be unhappy.

sp.speaker: Arab.
sp.p: I pity your circumstances.

sp.speaker: Lov.
sp.p: Look you Captain— there's your friend.

sp.speaker: Carel.
sp.p: Come, Captain— how is't▪

sp.speaker: Durz.
sp.p: Why, these Towns are such places, that a man can't tell where he is, tho' both his Eyes are open. I can walk so all about my Frigat, Fore and Aft, in my sleep, between Decks, or above Deck, and return into my Cabin without waking, but here I am forced to have a Pilot to steer me broad awake.

sp.speaker: Lov.
sp.p: They want one Witness more, and desire you—

sp.speaker: Carel.
sp.p: Captain, I leave you in good company; I'll be with you presently.

sp.speaker: Arab.
sp.p: Who is this?

sp.speaker: Lov.
sp.p: A brave Sea-Captain— Stout and Blunt— he was Born in a Ship, and scarce knows any thing of Land Affairs.

sp.speaker: Hil.
sp.p: He looks as ruff as a Storm.

sp.speaker: Arab.
sp.p: I like him well; he looks as if fighting was his business.

sp.speaker: Jac.
sp.p: He's not very curious in his Dress.

sp.speaker: Lov.
sp.p: Captain, how do you like these Ladies?

sp.speaker: Capt.
sp.p: Three very snug Frigats, well Rigg'd; 'twere pity too but they were as well Man'd.

sp.speaker: Lov.
sp.p: E'r you come Aboard one of these— you must be new Rigg'd your self; I must carry you to a Ward-robe.

sp.speaker: Capt.
sp.p: What place is that, do they fight or Drink there?

sp.speaker: Lov.
sp.p: 'Tis a Storehouse for the Body, you must lay by this Sea habit for a Land Dress, the Ladies won't like the smell of Pitch and Tar.

sp.speaker: Capt.
sp.p: Not like it! Which of them won't like it?

sp.speaker: Hil.
sp.p: He'll beat us anon.

sp.speaker: Jac.
sp.p: I begin to be afraid.

sp.speaker: Durz.
sp.p: But what do you with these Ladies here?

sp.speaker: Lov.
sp.p: Court them, Gallant them.

sp.speaker: Durz.
sp.p: What's that?

sp.speaker: Lov.
sp.p: We make love to them: You must have a Mistress now you are come ashore.

sp.speaker: Durz.
sp.p: Must I? Which of them?

sp.speaker: Lov.
sp.p: Her you like best, Captain

sp.speaker: Durz.
sp.p: I like them all; I am for a whole Tier of them.

sp.speaker: Lov.
sp.p: Every man must have his share— make choice of her you think handsomest.

sp.speaker: Durz.
sp.p: But how must a man know a handsome Woman?

sp.speaker: Lov.
sp.p: Here's a Pattern to choose by— observe: Shows Arabella to the Captain. A Forehead high and fair— Eyes black and sparkling— Cheeks plump, not by Art, but Nature painted— A Mouth little, red Lips and white Teeth; a Pearly Portcullis to a Ruby Gate.

sp.speaker: Durz.
sp.p: That's fine.

sp.speaker: Lov.
sp.p: A Chin dimpl'd; in that little Pit a thousand Hearts lye Buried.

sp.speaker: Durz.
sp.p: They are thrown in then, as fast as we heave Dead men over-board in a Sea Fight.

sp.speaker: Hil.
sp.p: Well said, Captain.

sp.speaker: Lov.
sp.p: A Neck smooth, fat, white, and soft as the doun on Swans.

sp.speaker: Durz.
sp.p: Ay, that—

sp.speaker: Lov.
sp.p: Breasts hard and round, their motions pant beholders Hearts into an extasie; they rise and fall like Waves blown up by gentle Winds.— Do but lay your hand here, Captain. Durzo touches Arabella 's Breasts.

sp.speaker: Durz.
sp.p: O, O, feel here! Durzo pulls Lovell 's hand to his breast.

sp.speaker: Lov.
sp.p: Ah! your heart beats high, we shall have boysterous weather anon— I perceive it coming.

sp.speaker: Jac.
sp.p: How. is't Captain?

sp.speaker: Durz.
sp.p: My heart begins to leap and play like a Porpice before a Storm.

sp.speaker: Lov.
sp.p: Look you here, Captain— an Arm and Hand small, white and plump, the vaulting Blood blushing through the fair skin like a Lawn. Veil▪ spread o'r a Bed of Roses. Touch her Captain. Lovell puts Arabella 's Arm into Durzo 's hand.

sp.speaker: Durz.
sp.p: Oh, how fine it is to stroak such Limbs.

sp.speaker: Hil.
sp.p: Beauty, I see, will soften and polish him.

sp.speaker: Arab.
sp.p: Now tell me Captain, what do you think of me?

sp.speaker: Durz.
sp.p: As of a Woman.

sp.speaker: Lov.
sp.p: Is that all?

sp.speaker: Durz.
sp.p: Why, a Woman's the finest thing I ever saw, except a Cannon Mounted, and a Ship under Sail.

sp.speaker: Lov.
sp.p: Now Captain, if you like her, claim her for your Mistress: Love her, Court her, Gallant her, and do your best.— Win her and wear her; that's fair play.

sp.speaker: Durz.
sp.p: Will you give her me?

sp.speaker: Lov.
sp.p: If you can get her.

sp.speaker: Durz.
sp.p: Why, I can take her up in my Arms and run away with her.

sp.speaker: Arab.
sp.p: And whither wou'd you carry me?

sp.speaker: Durz.
sp.p: Aboard— and he that dares come to take you from me there, had as good leap into a Blazing Fireship, or kiss Thundr.

sp.speaker: Arab.
sp.p: But I am no Lawful Prize, if you take me by force: By the Laws of Love you must Court me, and win me fairly.

sp.speaker: Lov.
sp.p: You must get her good Will, Captain.

sp.speaker: Durz.
sp.p: I thought I had her Will when I had her— but now I think on't I have been told, That a Womans Will shifts more Points than the Wind. But if she Sail any Point of the Compass, I'll hale her in I warrant you.

sp.speaker: Lov.
sp.p: Well said Captain.

sp.speaker: Arab.
sp.p: I'll hold you Chase I warrant you—

sp.speaker: Jac.
sp.p: Have a care of Storms.

sp.speaker: Hil.
sp.p: And look you don't slip your Anchor, Captain.

sp.speaker: Gree.
sp.p: Come, come, here you stand Chit chat, and forget the main business of Life; Supper's on the Table and half cold. Walk in and line your Christmas Coffers, come.

sp.speaker: Hil.
sp.p: Well advis'd, Mr. Justice, they that won't follow set them in the Stocks.— This is the Jolliest old Blade for Eating! His Mouth's like a Mill, always grinding— Come Servant, Usher me in handsomly.

sp.speaker: Carel.
sp.p: I'll Eat and Drink to enable my self in your Service.

sp.speaker: Arab.
sp.p: Captain, you shall be my Guest; you are not arriv'd to that degree yet to live by Love.

sp.speaker: Durz.
sp.p: I'll take in a little Ballast, that I may Sail the Stiffer.

div.head: SCENE I.
div.stage: Scene draws, and discovers Alderman Furr, Sir Barnaby Buffler, Justice Greedy, Mr. Lovell, Mr. Careless, Captain, Jacinta, Hilaria, Arabella; Dash entring, shov'd in by Toby— at a distance Beatrice, Waiting.

sp.speaker: Fur.
sp.p: GEntlemen, you are all welcome: Sir Barnaby, my service to you. O, Mr. Dash, where are you?— Come, take a Chair and sit down.

sp.speaker: Dash.
sp.p: O Lord, Sir, I dare not presume— Retreats.

sp.speaker: Fur.
sp.p: Come, come, sit down— sit down.

sp.speaker: Dash.
sp.p: At your Worship's Table! I have more Breeding; an't please you, I'll Sup with the Gentlewoman, by her leave, when you have done.

sp.speaker: Fur.
sp.p: Sir Barnaby, pray speak to him to sit down.

sp.speaker: Sir Bar.
sp.p: Sit down— Better be unmannerly than troublesome.

sp.speaker: Dash.
sp.p: No offence, I hope. Dash sitting down speaks to Lovell.

sp.speaker: Lov.
sp.p: No, no, sit down. He sits at a distance from the Table.

sp.speaker: Fur.
sp.p: Reach him his Hat there.

sp.speaker: Dash.
sp.p: Let it lye, Friend.

sp.speaker: Fur.
sp.p: Reach it him, I say.

sp.speaker: Dash.
sp.p: I beseech your Worship▪

sp.speaker: Fur.
sp.p: Put it on.

sp.speaker: Dash.
sp.p: By no means.

sp.speaker: Fur.
sp.p: Put it on his head.

sp.speaker: Dash.
sp.p: I beseech your Worship hold me excus'd: I am a poor Scribe.

p.hi: Be it better, or be it worse, be rul'd by him that bears the Purse.

sp.speaker: Dash.
sp.p: Your Worships are wiser than I am. Dash puts on his Hat, and sits at a distance from the Table.

sp.speaker: Hil.
sp.p: A pure fellow this, he sits as if he were afraid of the Table.

sp.speaker: Arab.
sp.p: Friend, you can't reach.

sp.speaker: Fur.
sp.p: Draw your Chair nearer.

sp.speaker: Dash.
sp.p: I thank your Worship.

sp.speaker: Fur.
sp.p: Shove it nearer the Table for him. Toby behind shoves the Chair nearer, and he thrusts it back as often with his foot.

sp.speaker: Dash.
sp.p: Very well, I thank you friend.

sp.speaker: Fur.
sp.p: Nearer yet.

sp.speaker: Dash.
sp.p: So, very well, very well; so, so, very well, very well. And sits with his Napkin cross his left Arm.

sp.speaker: Hil.
sp.p: Friend, My Service to you.

sp.speaker: Dash.
sp.p: O Lord— And please your Ladiship, Drink to me! Dash starts from the Table, and falls down on his knees, wiping his Mouth with his Sleeve.

sp.speaker: Fur.
sp.p: Keep— keep your Seat friend.

sp.speaker: Dash.
sp.p: Madam, your poor Scribe thanks you.—

sp.speaker: Arab.
sp.p: Drink to me Mr. Dash, I'll pledge you.

sp.speaker: Dash.
sp.p: Your Ladiship must excuse me; I dare not be so bold. Mistress, my Service to you. Turns round and Drinks to Beatrice behind standing up; she makes a Curtesy and smiles.

sp.speaker: Beatr.
sp.p: Thank you Sir.

sp.speaker: Carel.
sp.p: Look you, Madam, he's a very well-bred man.

sp.speaker: Greed.
sp.p: Give me a Glass of Wine— here's ado about nothing— I am— almost choak'd with all this Ceremony.

sp.speaker: Fur.
sp.p: Now fall to, Friend.

sp.speaker: Dash.
sp.p: Thank your Worship, I don't spare▪

sp.speaker: Hil.
sp.p: Unfold your Napkin Mr. Dash.

sp.speaker: Dash.
sp.p: 'Tis very well, I heartily thank your Ladiship.

sp.speaker: Arab.
sp.p: Spread it before you, you'll grease your Clothes.

sp.speaker: Dash.
sp.p: I thank you kindly— I have a Handkerchief for that. Dash speaks with his Mouth full, and spreads his Handkerchief on his knee.

sp.speaker: Greed.
sp.p: Sir Barnaby, your Ladies health to you.

sp.speaker: Sir Barn.
sp.p: I thank you, Sir.

sp.speaker: Greed.
sp.p: You don't Eat heartily Sir Barnaby.

sp.speaker: Sir Barn.
sp.p: I am no great Supper-man.

sp.speaker: Greed.
sp.p: Don't you eat Suppers?

sp.speaker: Sir Barn.
sp.p: Seldom: One Meal a day makes a Man healthy and wealthy.

sp.speaker: Greed.
sp.p: On one Meal a day we may live, on two we may thrive, but three must make us fat. And I say, Sir Barnaby— Eat and be Rich, Fast and dye in a Ditch. Come, come, Hunger breeds Knaves: A full Belly thinks least harm.

sp.speaker: Sir Barn.
sp.p: I am for what is wholesome: Light Suppers make clean Sheets.

sp.speaker: Greed.
sp.p: But my Grannam taught me better— When the Belly's full the Bones are at rest: Eat nothing and Dream of the Devil.

sp.speaker: Sir Barn.
sp.p: Several Men several Minds; I sleep best without. Custom is a second Nature.

sp.speaker: Greed.
sp.p: Sir Barnaby, Ill Customs are better broken than kept: If I went Supperless to Bed, my Guts wou'd croak all Night like Frogs in a Fish-pond.

sp.speaker: Sir Barn.
sp.p: Nature is bent to its own Ruin: Gluttony destroys more than the Sword.

sp.speaker: Greed.
sp.p: Monstrum Horrendum; that men can hold Arguments against their Bellies.

sp.speaker: Fur.
sp.p: How now Mr. Dash. Dash rises from Table with his Napkin and Plate, and makes a low Leg.

sp.speaker: Dash.
sp.p: I have Supp'd I thank you— and now I'll wait upon your Worship.

sp.speaker: Fur.
sp.p: No, no— take his Plate and Napkin there— Beatrice offers to take it and he won't let her, but carry it himself to the side board.

sp.speaker: Beatr.
sp.p: Let me set it by.

sp.speaker: Dash.
sp.p: Excuse me there, forsooth, I understand better.

sp.speaker: Tob.
sp.p: Here are two Women enquire for Mr. Justice Greedy.

sp.speaker: Greed.
sp.p: For me? I'll not stir from Table for no body: Can't a man eat in quiet? I'll throw up my Commission.

sp.speaker: Lov.
sp.p: O Sir, let them come in. Exit Waiter.

sp.speaker: Hil.
sp.p: If it be Justice business we may have some sport.

sp.speaker: Greed.
sp.p: Call them in— Come forward, what's your business?

div.head: SCENE II.
div.stage: Enter Mrs. Breeder, and Mrs. Dazie, and Children.

sp.speaker: Breed.
sp.p: We are come and please you, to make Oath against a person that is fled to this Town to be married, and disowns both us and his Children.

sp.speaker: Greed.
sp.p: Who is it?

sp.speaker: Dazie.
sp.p: One Sir Barnaby Buffler.

sp.speaker: Greed.
sp.p: Here he is, speak to his face.

sp.speaker: Dazie.
sp.p: O Sir Barnaby, have we found you!

sp.speaker: Breed.
sp.p: Were you so cunning, to go so far from home to steal a marriage, that we might not hear on't?— But we are here to forbid the Banes.

sp.speaker: Sir Barn.
sp.p: What mean you Woman?

sp.speaker: Breed.
sp.p: Ah Gentlemen, wonder not at us, for this wicked Sir Barnaby, five years ago, tempted my honesty, and with solemn promises of marriage prevailed over my weakness, and got me with Child.

sp.speaker: Greed.
sp.p: What! and eat no Suppers.

sp.speaker: Fur.
sp.p: How's this!

sp.speaker: Breed.
sp.p: And to encrease my sorrow,— I had two at a birth.

sp.speaker: Greed.
sp.p: What, and he Eat no Suppers.

sp.speaker: Hil.
sp.p: O rare Sir Barnaby.

sp.speaker: Fur.
sp.p: Hold you your Clack Gossip. To Hilaria.

sp.speaker: Sir Bar.
sp.p: An impudent Quean— I never saw her— I should not know her if I had met her in my Dish.

sp.speaker: Breed.
sp.p: If I had never known you, I had never Breed weeps. known sorrow.

sp.speaker: Jac.
sp.p: Alas poor Woman.

sp.speaker: Sir Bar.
sp.p: Mind her not, she's a quean; 'Tis no more pity to see her Weep, than to see a Goose go barefoot.

sp.speaker: Dazie.
sp.p: You'll say you don't know me too, I warrant you.

sp.speaker: Greed.
sp.p: What has Sir Barnaby been Tennant to your Copy-hold too.

sp.speaker: Dazie.
sp.p: E'en so to my sorrow.

sp.speaker: Fur.
sp.p: What, both!

sp.speaker: Sir Bar.
sp.p: A Couple of Carryons— Ne'er a Barrel better Herring.

sp.speaker: Greed.
sp.p: Come, come, here's matter for me, Greed. turns his Chair from the Table. give me my Chair.

sp.speaker: Sir Bar.
sp.p: Ay Mr. Justice, take 'em Coram nobis.

sp.speaker: Grerd.
sp.p: I'll examine these matters according to Authority.

sp.speaker: Breed.
sp.p:
Thô he won't know us, let's see if he don't know these, come here Children, kneel Johnny,— kneel down little Sarah, ask Father
blessing, and let's see if he can be so unnatural to disown his own Flesh and Blood.

sp.speaker: Dazie.
sp.p: And do thou kneel Tommy, ask blessing— The Children all kneel down. 'tis Nown Daddy.

sp.speaker: 3 Chil.
sp.p: Pray Father— pray Daddy— pray Father, pray Daddy.

sp.speaker: Sir Bar.
sp.l: Pray Father, pray Daddy. Sir Bar. sits down on his Hams, and mocks the Children.
You Jackdaw's you, hold your gaping.

sp.speaker: Greed.
sp.p: Come before Justice— here you that han't told your story yet.— But first, what's your name.

sp.speaker: Breed.
sp.p: Elizabeth Breeder.

sp.speaker: Greed.
sp.p: And Yours.

sp.speaker: Dazie.
sp.p: Sarah Dazie, and please you—

sp.speaker: Greed.
sp.p: And what come you for? what's your complaint?

sp.speaker: Dazie.
sp.p: And please your Worship Mr. Justice.

sp.speaker: Greed.
sp.p: Speak out—

sp.speaker: Dazie.
sp.p: And please you this Sir Barnaby—

sp.speaker: Greed.
sp.p: Well,— but first what are you—

sp.speaker: Dazie.
sp.p: I am a very honest Farmer's Daughter—

sp.speaker: Greed.
sp.p: I believe it wou'd a been better for you, that you had been a Farmer's honest Daughter.

sp.speaker: Dazie.
sp.p: I had been so and please you,— had it not been for Sir Barnaby.

sp.speaker: Greed.
sp.p: Why, what did he do?

sp.speaker: Dazie.
sp.p: He knows well enough, what was done in the great barn.

sp.speaker: Greed.
sp.p: What he thrash'd you there did he?

sp.speaker: Dazie.
sp.p: Here is the fruit of his labour, hold up thy Head Tommy; look you Gentlewoman, is he not as like, as if he was spit out of his Mouth?

sp.speaker: Hil.
sp.p: He has his very Eyes, and the make of his Face.

sp.speaker: Breed.
sp.p: And see here a pair of pretty Twins, so like the Father.

sp.speaker: Jac.
sp.p: These have his Nose, his Forehead, and Chin exactly.

sp.speaker: Fur.
sp.p: It cannot be deny'd, but they are pretty Children.

sp.speaker: Sir Bar.
sp.p: Ye all Dream, they are neither like, nor pretty— nor nothing. These are impudent queans.

sp.speaker: Arab.
sp.p: This is an abuse to my Brother, design'd to hinder his Marriage.

sp.speaker: Lov.
sp.p: 'Tis combination, Mr. Justice, take care of these baggages: Let 'em kiss the Whipping-post.

sp.speaker: Greed.
sp.p: Let me alone. (Justice goes step by step.) Well, and you Mrs. Breeder, you say these two Children were begotten on your natural body, by Sir Barnaby, and born out of lawful Wedlock.

sp.speaker: Breed.
sp.p: Yes Sir, but not without a Contract.

sp.speaker: Greed.
sp.p: Well, stand you by— but hold, hold,— one question or two more. What were you when this was done.

sp.speaker: Breed.
sp.p: A Chambermaid.

sp.speaker: Greed.
sp.p: And this was your Chamber practice, what, he did not Ravish you, did he?

sp.speaker: Breed.
sp.p: Not against my Will.

sp.speaker: Om.
sp.p: Ha, ha, ha.

sp.speaker: Sir Bar.
sp.p: They both Lie faster, than a Dog can trot.

sp.speaker: Greed.
sp.p: Trouble not your self Sir Barnaby, they have both confess'd that these are bastard Children, consequently themselves to be Whores, I'll send 'em to the house of Correction.

sp.speaker: Breed.
sp.p: No, I lay claim to him for my Husband.

sp.speaker: Dazie.
sp.p: And so do I.

sp.speaker: Greed.
sp.p: And the Whipping post lays claim to you both. Come, give me Pen, Ink, and Paper, I'll make their Mittimus.

sp.speaker: Dash.
sp.p: Here and please your Worship, I have both. Dash pulls out Pen and Ink.

sp.speaker: Carl.
sp.p: Now Baggages, present, present—

sp.speaker: Breed.
sp.p: A word and please your Worship— Carl. speaks to Breed. and Daz.

sp.speaker: Greed.
sp.p: Well!—

sp.speaker: Breed.
sp.p: Here is a Collar of Brawn, which my Father sends you as a token of his respect, for your prudent moderation in this affair.

sp.speaker: Greed.
sp.p: Humph— Brawn— Brawn!— I say you are a notorious Baggage. Rare Brawn, rare Brawn! Aloud.

sp.speaker: Breed.
sp.p: 'Tis ready sou●'d for your Worships Eating.

sp.speaker: Greed.
sp.p: Speak softly— abuse so worthy a Person as Sir Barnaby! rare Brawn, there will be no living without Justice; delicate Brawn.— I'll make you an example.— Set it behind my Chair, rare Brawn, rare Brawn!

sp.speaker: Carl.
sp.p: He swallows the bribe.

sp.speaker: Lov.
sp.p: The Jades act it well.

sp.speaker: Dazie.
sp.p: Mr. Justice.

sp.speaker: Greed.
sp.p: What, now you'll Sing the second part to the some Tune, will ye.

sp.speaker: Dazie.
sp.p: My Mother has sent your Worship, this couple of fat Capons, for a present.

sp.speaker: Greed.
sp.p: Dainty Birds, speak for you! hang you.—

sp.speaker: Dazie.
sp.p: She was dairy Maid to your Worship's Mother.—

sp.speaker: Greed.
sp.p: No, no, Not I— you are a most impudent strumpet— dainty birds, dainty birds.

sp.speaker: Dazie.
sp.p: They are of her own Cramming.

sp.speaker: Greed.
sp.p: Softly— abuse such a Person as Sir Barnaby; dainty birds indeed! I'll swinge you both,— dainty birds. I am enrag'd, I shall never be able to do Justice with moderation. I'll— I'll— I'll— Ah— dainty birds.

sp.speaker: Carl.
sp.p: Mr. Justice, being these Women are come a great way, and have small Children to provide for, were it not better to lend 'em home again, than to keep 'em here, and put the Town to charge.

sp.speaker: Hil.
sp.p: Od's life, old Sir, discharge 'em; or let me be their bail.

sp.speaker: Greedy.
sp.p: Truly Sir, my Heart is mollified, I think with you 'twere best to send them back to their own Country, and Sir Barnaby may do well to give 'em a small Sum to bear their charges back.

sp.speaker: Sir Bar.
sp.p: Hang 'em— Not a Cross to bless themselves with— e'en let 'em go Byard on Ten-toes for me.

sp.speaker: Fur.
sp.p: Well, here's Angels a piece upon condition, they trouble us no more with this clammer.

sp.speaker: Breed. Dazie.
sp.p: We thank your Worship.

sp.speaker: Greed.
sp.p: Dainty birds— dainty birds.

sp.speaker: Fur.
sp.p: And hereafter, if we find good ground for what you say, I'll prevail with Sir Barnaby, to allow some thing yearly for maintainnance of your Children.

sp.speaker: Greed.
sp.p: Dainty Birds—

sp.speaker: Breed. Dazie.
sp.p: Thank you Sir,— thank you.

sp.speaker: Greed.
sp.p: Go, go, get you gone— you are beholden to these Friends.

sp.speaker: Breed.
sp.p: Go Johnny— go Sarah, you may never see your Father more, therefore ask him blessing.

sp.speaker: Dazie.
sp.p: Ay, do Tommy, ask Father blessing too.

sp.speaker: 3 Chil.
sp.p: Pray Father— pray Father.

sp.speaker: Sir Bar.
sp.p: Bastards, Whores-birds! the Devil take ye all.

sp.speaker: 3 Chil.
sp.p: Pray Father— pray Daddy, &c. Sir Barnaby runs off.

sp.speaker: Breed. Dazie.
sp.p: Follow him Children, follow him.

sp.speaker: 3 Child.
sp.p: Pray Father,— pray Daddy,— The three Children run after him. pray Father,— pray Daddy,— pray Father.

sp.speaker: Hil.
sp.p: Ha, ha, ha,— Sir Barnaby and Children. Exeunt.

sp.speaker: Arab.
sp.p: Poor Infants.

sp.speaker: Carl.
sp.p: Hark you, hark you, Frailties; the boul of Punch is ready, the Captain and I will come and be merry with you for an hour—

sp.speaker: Dazie.
sp.p: We'll expect you.

sp.speaker: Breed.
sp.p: Your Servant Sir. Carless whispers Breed. and Dazie, Hilaria, hearkens behind his back.

sp.speaker: Hil.
sp.p: Madam, my Spark and your Captain, I suspect by that whisper are wickedly bent— I over heard a paw word.

sp.speaker: Greed.
sp.p: Come Gentlemen, let's deliver Sir Barnaby from the Philistines, and bring him back.

sp.speaker: Carl.
sp.p: Ay, we'll all help, we'll drive away the Whores, I warrant you.

sp.speaker: Hil.
sp.p: Will you so, we'll watch your motions— come Madam.

sp.speaker: Arab.
sp.p: 'Tis e'en as you say— Carl. Durzo. Greed. Lovel. Dash. Arabel beat Toby— Exeunt.

sp.speaker: Greed.
sp.p: Rare Brawn— delicate Brawn— dainty Birds— dainty Birds—

sp.speaker: Hil.
sp.p: Mr. Justice— rare Brawn, delicate Brawn— rare Birds, dainty Birds—

sp.speaker: Greed.
sp.p: You are a wag, you are a wag, Mr. Dash, bring the Collar after me.

sp.speaker: Jac.
sp.p: You see Sir, what a Person you are going to Marry me to.

sp.speaker: Fur
sp.p: This is nothing, at best, but a trick of Youth, many a Woman would be glad to see so good proofs of a Man, that is to be her Husband, mind you his Estate.

sp.speaker: Jac.
sp.p: What is a Wife better for an Estate, when he's so Covetous.

sp.speaker: Fur.
sp.p: Thrift will encrease it— 'twill be all your Children's.

sp.speaker: Jac.
sp.p: He's Jealous too.

sp.speaker: Fur.
sp.p: You call that Jealousy which is prudence.

sp.speaker: Jac.
sp.p: And obstinate.

sp.speaker: Fur.
sp.p: Humor him—

sp.speaker: Jac.
sp.p: And Conceited.

sp.speaker: Fur.
sp.p: Say as he sayes.

sp.speaker: Jac.
sp.p: And slovenly.

sp.speaker: Fur.
sp.p: Great Wits are generally so. Do you not observe, that every word he speaks is a sentence.

sp.speaker: Jac.
sp.p: His is old fashion'd— Grand-mother Wit— he is a meer bundle of Proverbs,— I shall have him— nick name'd— and call'd my Solomon.

sp.speaker: Fur.
sp.p: You are a Fool to argue so against your own good▪

sp.speaker: Jac.
sp.p: Besides, Sir, he's Old.

sp.speaker: Fur.
sp.p: He'll Die the sooner, go— there's a salve for that sore▪ Here he comes, compose your self.—

div.head: SCENE IV.
div.stage: Enter Sir Barnaby, Justice Greedy, and Dash to them.

sp.speaker: Bar.
sp.p: These Carrions have put me Quite out of my Byass, I can Get into my right geers again, on the suddain.

sp.speaker: Greed.
sp.p: Hang 'em— think no more on 'em.

sp.speaker: Sir Bar.
sp.p: Now Father-in-law, to draw to a conclusion in our affair.

sp.speaker: Fur.
sp.p: The sooner the better.

sp.speaker: Sir Bar.
sp.p: And to end all in a word, for A word to the Wise is sufficient.

sp.speaker: Fur.
sp.p: Very good.

sp.speaker: Sir Bar.
sp.p: The Marriage writings being sign'd and seal'd betwixt us—

sp.speaker: Fur.
sp.p: They are so—

sp.speaker: Sir Bar.
sp.p: And I being to Marry your Daughter to Morrow, For delaye are dangerous.

sp.speaker: Fur.
sp.p: True.

sp.speaker: Sir Bar.
sp.p: Than I may now account her as my Wife.

sp.speaker: Fur.
sp.p: You may so—

sp.speaker: Sir Bar.
sp.p: Than there is but one thing more remains necessary to be done to night.

sp.speaker: Fur.
sp.p: What's that?

sp.speaker: Sir Bar.
sp.p: Considering that she is as my Wife,— and that we are lodged here in a publick Inn— where there are some passengers already, and may yet be many more— and that Inns are subject to disturbances at any hour, it will be more for her safety and my honour, that she be this night put under my guard and protection. She shall be lodg'd in the Chamber, betwixt mine and my Brothers, where we can both of us, hear and be ready if occasion should require. For many things fall out, betwixt the Cup and the Lip, and That may happen in a Minute, that does not otherwise fall out in an Age, and It is better to prevent a mischief, than to remedy it.

sp.speaker: Fur.
sp.p: It is so. Be it as you please Sir Barnaby.

sp.speaker: Sir Bar.
sp.p: I do than require, that you now deliver your Daughter to me, with your own proper hand— with all your right, title, claim, and interest that you have in Fur gives his Daughters hand to Sir Barnaby. and to her.

sp.speaker: Fur.
sp.p: Here Sir—

sp.speaker: Sir Bar.
sp.p: Observe Gentlemen— say after me,— I deliver to you, my Daughter— &c.

sp.speaker: Fur.
