sp.p: I deliver to you my Daughter, Fur. gives his Daugters hand to Sir Bar. with all my right, title, claim and interest, that I have in and to her, to be made your lawful wedded Wife.

sp.speaker: Sir Bar.
sp.p: So, I love to do all things with discretion, and to make all things sure, Fast bind, fast find.

sp.speaker: Jacin.
sp.p: A fine Bargain indeed.

sp.speaker: Greed.
sp.p: You act very prudently, Sir.

sp.speaker: Sir Bar.
sp.p: A thing— once well done, is twice done. And now Sir, you shall see how punctual I will be to you▪ Dash give me the little Paper I gave you.

sp.speaker: Dash.
sp.p: Here and please you.

sp.speaker: Sir Bar.
sp.p: Reach me the Pen and Ink— Sir Barnaby writes his name, and Greed, and Dash, do the same. He gives it taking of the Seal. So Mr Justice, pray observe; here I subscribe my name.

sp.speaker: Greed.
sp.p: Hum— m— m— hum— m— m— ah—

sp.speaker: Sir Bar.
sp.p: See Gentlemen, I take off the Seal; here Sir, I deliver you this— before Witness.

sp.speaker: Fur.
sp.p: What is't?—

sp.speaker: Sir Bar.
sp.p: Read it I pray, I think 'tis right.

body.p: I Do acknowledge to have had and received of and from Mr. Benjamin Furr, Alderman and Citizen of London, his sole and only Daughter, call'd and known by the Christian name of Jacinta, with all her Conditions and Qualities, be they good or bad, with all absolute promise, full intent and purpose, on my part, to make her my true and lawful Wedded Wife, by Ten of the Clock to Morrow-morning, being the third of May, and the Day following the Date of this present writing— In Testimony whereof, I have hereunto set my Hand and Seal.

sp.speaker: Sir Bar.
sp.p: So, now do you two Witness it.

sp.speaker: Fur.
sp.p:
Witness.
Cormorant Greedy.
Zachariah Dash.

sp.speaker: Jac.
sp.p: Was ever the like extravagance.

sp.speaker: Fur.
sp.p: What can be the meaning of this Receipt, does he think I lend or sell him my Daughter?

sp.speaker: Greed.
sp.p: No matter— 'tis his fancy,— it does you no hurt.

sp.speaker: Sir Bar.
sp.p: Now Sir, I'll see my Wife safe up to her Chamber, and bid you all good Night.

sp.speaker: Greed.
sp.p: For Bed already Sir Barnaby?

sp.speaker: Sir Bar.
sp.l: Ay, Early to Bed, and early to Rise,

l.hi: Will make a Man Healthy, Wealthy, and Wise.

sp.speaker: Fur.
sp.p: Heaven send my Daughter to do well,— this Receipt won't out of my mind. But come, she's Marry'd to a good Estate, and that covers a multitude of faults.

sp.speaker: Greed.
sp.p: Ay, ay, well enough— dainty Birds— dainty Birds.—

div.head: SCENE V.
div.stage: Enter Mrs. Breeder, Dazie, and Boy.

sp.speaker: Breed.
sp.p: Come, where's this bowl of Punch?

sp.speaker: Boy.
sp.p: There Madam— Boy Exit.

sp.speaker: Breed.
sp.p: Tell me Mother, pray now do, &c.

sp.speaker: Dazie.
sp.p: She got Money by't, she got Money by't, &c.

sp.speaker: Carl.
sp.p: Merry Girls Captain.

sp.speaker: Capt.
sp.p: Cheary my Mates, cheary.

sp.speaker: Breed.
sp.p: Courage Captain— give me your hand, I love a Tarpaling at my heart.

sp.speaker: Capt.
sp.p: Come, let's drink about, my service to you.

sp.speaker: Breed,
sp.p: My service to you! there's a sneaking compliment, you'd have said as much to an honest Woman.

sp.speaker: Capt.
sp.p: I can't talk at your rate, but if you are for Ship shape language, downright drinking, or will come to grapling, I am for you.

sp.speaker: Carl.
sp.p: Bid the Musick come in Ladies, the Captain has brought his Boats crew to entertain you with a Song and a Dance.

div.stage: After the Song and Dance, Enter Greedy; Hillaria, Arabella, in Mens Habits.

sp.speaker: Greed.
sp.p: By your leave Gallants, I am come to be merry with you, and have brought a couple of young Friends with me, they are going to Travel, to Morrow they are for Dover.

sp.speaker: Dazie.
sp.p: They are welcome into our Cabin, I wish we had better entertainment.

sp.speaker: Greed.
sp.p: What, are not honest Gentlemen, handsome Girls, a bowl of Punch, and good Musick entertainment!

sp.speaker: Arab.
sp.p: I fear we shall be uncivil—!

sp.speaker: Carl;
sp.p: That you can hardly be in our Company.

sp.speaker: Breed.
sp.p: Lord, these are the two prettiest Youths!

sp.speaker: Dazie.
sp.p: I long for a kiss of 'em.

sp.speaker: Carl.
sp.p: You may Sing, Drink, Swear, Roar, and Ruffle, and do as you please.

sp.speaker: Greed.
sp.p: They came of a good kind, Greed▪ shoves 'em to the Women, they salute. they only want entering. To them Boys, to 'em— Hollow.

sp.speaker: Hil.
sp.p: By your leave Ladies.

sp.speaker: Capt.
sp.p: Come, now bowze it away.

sp.speaker: Carl.
sp.p: Every one his Dish. Ladies your Healths.

sp.speaker: Hil.
sp.p: Your Healths Ladies.

sp.speaker: Arab.
sp.p: Your Healths Ladies.

sp.speaker: Greed.
sp.p: Ay, ay, about with it.

lg.l: Than give me a full Boul,
And let me drink, without Controul.
In spight of the Vicar, and his dull teaching.
We'll take of our Liquor, and ne'er mind his preaching;
Let him Damn us to the Pit hole.

sp.speaker: Capt.
sp.p: There's somthing in that.

sp.speaker: Hil.
sp.p: Come, let's have t'other dish, Sir, to you.

sp.speaker: Arab.
sp.p: And to you Captain.

sp.speaker: Capt.
sp.p: Come, about Ship, all hands aloft.

sp.speaker: Hil.
sp.p: Now, Sir, pledge me on this Ladies Lips, three go downs upon reputation.

sp.speaker: Arab.
sp.p: And Captain, pledge me the like here.

sp.speaker: Carl.
sp.p: Two brisk little Devils. They kiss and ruffle the Women, and whisper to 'em.

sp.speaker: Greed-
sp.p: I told you they were no Mongrels.

sp.speaker: Breed-
sp.p: Where will you meet us. Whilst the Dance continues, Greedy nods his Head to the Tune, Drinks, and now and then Sings, I have a thirsty Soul.

sp.speaker: Hil.
sp.p: Steal to the Inn over the way.

sp.speaker: Arab.
sp.p: Bid the Chamberlain show you into Justices Chamber.

sp.speaker: Dazie.
sp.p: You'll not fail to follow. Hil. Arab. Breed. and Dazie. whisper all the while.

sp.speaker: Carl.
sp.p: What, whispering! It spoyls company.

sp.speaker: Breed.
sp.p: Mum.

sp.speaker: Dazie.
sp.p: Enough.

sp.speaker: Hil.
sp.p: I beg your pardon.

sp.speaker: Boy.
sp.p: Sir, a Messenger has brought you this Letter, and stays for an Answer.

sp.speaker: Breed.
sp.p: We'll take this opportunity. Ex. Breed. and Dazie

sp.speaker: Greed.
sp.p: Away, away, you luscious Jades to my Chamber, mind your Q. hum— Captain, my service to you— I have a thirsty Soul, &c.

sp.speaker: Carl.
sp.p:
What's here, a Billet doux. Reads.
GAllant, I know not what's the cause, but I am very Melancholy, pray come and spend an hour or two with me, e'er I go to Bed, for I find I have an inclination to your company, perhaps the sight of you may cure me. Bring the Captain along with you, to divert his Lady, for she is in the dumps too.
Hillaria.
This 'tis to have the company of honest Women, they presently grow troublesome.

sp.speaker: Hil.
sp.p: Why Sir?

sp.speaker: Carl.
sp.p: If they be of the dull sober sort, a Man can hardly get acquaintance with them, but they fall flat in love; if of a spritely gay humour, they presently grow impertinent, and will ever be sending such notes as these to a Man, or running after him.

sp.speaker: Hil.
sp.p: But is she handsom, that gives you this invitation?

sp.speaker: Carl.
sp.p: Yes, hang her, she's well enough.

sp.speaker: Hil.
sp.p: Than you shou'd take it for a kindness.

sp.speaker: Carl.
sp.p: But I wonder Women han't the Wit to know when a Man cares for their Love, or their company; for to be sure, when he has a mind to either, he'll be coming or sending to them.

sp.speaker: Durz.
sp.p: Won't you make sail towards them?

sp.speaker: Carl.
sp.p: Do you think I'll leave good sociable company, for a dull honest Wench.

sp.speaker: Arab.
sp.p: She'll take it ill.

sp.speaker: Carl.
sp.p: I have a better Opinion of her Wit, than to think she'd desir't, if she knew how the case stands— boy bid the Messenger tell her he can't find me; I'll make such visits, when I have no better company— but where are our Women.

sp.speaker: Boy.
sp.p: They went out just as you began to read the Letter.

sp.speaker: Greed.
sp.p: Hum— come let's mind our Punch.— I have a thirsty Soul—

sp.speaker: Carl.
sp.p: Was this your whispering; young Squire, you don't play me fair play, you ought not to take up another Man's Dice.— And Captain, where's your Lady.

sp.speaker: Capt.
sp.p: What has she set her sails too, and stole away like a Cowardly Enemy in a dark night.

sp.speaker: Carl.
sp.p: Go down Boy, we'll pay below. Boy exit. Gentlemen you make too bold with us; To take one Woman from us, 'twas ill manners, to rob us of both, Mallice and ill nature.

sp.speaker: Hil.
sp.p: I do it by way of reprisal, you took one from me, and we have got two from you.

sp.speaker: Carl.
sp.p: I take one from you.

sp.speaker: Hil.
sp.p: Yes, I have had a long Intreague with a Lady named Hillaria, I have followed her from London, and here I find you are become her Servant.

sp.speaker: Carl.
sp.p: I was ignorant of any such pretensions.

sp.speaker: Hil.
sp.p: I shall spoyl your Markets theretoo; and tell her that she's impertinent to send after you— and all that— and when you can find no better company, you'll come to her— and all that.

sp.speaker: Carl.
sp.p: Nay, than I'll take another course with you. Come Sir. Draws.

sp.speaker: Capt.
sp.p: Ay, now there's some work towards, I have lost my Pinace too, which is he that I am to give a broad side to?

sp.speaker: Arab.
sp.p: I have a Sword to entertain you, as fierce as you look.

sp.speaker: Capt.
sp.p: God— a mercy little Piccaroon, huzza— away with't.

sp.speaker: Greed.
sp.p: Keep the peace in the King's name.— I'll steal after the Women, I am enflam'd with Punch, and they shall lay the fumes. Greed. Ex.

sp.speaker: Hil.
sp.p: Surely Sir, you'll not be so Mad to fight for one you don't Love.

sp.speaker: Carl.
sp.p: Look you Sir, thô I scorn to tell her so, or any of her Sex, yet I do Love her, will Love her, must Love her, and no body else shall Love her.

sp.speaker: Hil.
sp.p: But I do, will, and shall Love her better than you.

sp.speaker: Carl.
sp.p: Come, give me a proof on't then.

sp.speaker: Hil.
sp.p: Yes, Sir, I will give you a proof on't— Hil. Arab. throw of their Periwig. lie there Periwig.

sp.speaker: Arab.
sp.p: And mine there.

sp.speaker: Hil.
sp.p: What do you think of me, now my Manhood's off.

sp.speaker: Arab.
sp.p: And Captain, how do you like a Woman in Breeches?

sp.speaker: Capt.
sp.p: Hey, how wind you now!

sp.speaker: Hil.
sp.p: Alas poor Gallant! observe how you are cheated of your Mistresses,— ha, ha,— farewel Gallant.

sp.speaker: Arab.
sp.p: And Captain stick to your bowl of Punch.

sp.speaker: Carl.
sp.p: Hark you, stay—

sp.speaker: Hil.
sp.p: No, Women are so impertinent, Men will come after them, when they Love 'em; Adieu. Hil. Arab. Exeunt.

sp.speaker: Carl.
sp.p: Gad, they are too unconsciable to deprive us of our Women, and than to run away themselves. And now she knows I love her, she'll insult o'er me, what shall's do Captain?

sp.speaker: Capt.
sp.p: I'll observe what course you steer, I'll sail in your Wake.

sp.speaker: Carl.
sp.p: And those two Jades, to serve us such a trick! I thought they had some honour in 'em, but—

lg.l: I find that Women are by Nature guilty,
For be they Whores, or not Whores, they will gilt ye.

sp.speaker: Lov.
sp.p: THE truth is, she play'd the Tyrant with you, but you deserv'd that, and more.

sp.speaker: Carl.
sp.p: Were not the use and conversation of Women absolutely necessary for Mankind, I would forswear the whole Sex.

sp.speaker: Lov.
sp.p: I know by the Constitution of your body, you'd not be able to keep that Oath long. Yet I advise you to forswear all but one.

sp.speaker: Carl.
sp.p: That is, you'd have me Marry.

sp.speaker: Lov.
sp.p: Yes, you'd find more comfort in a Wife, than in ten Mistresses.

sp.speaker: Carl.
sp.p: If what you say be true; why do most Husbands in this Age, (which I take to be wiser than any that's past,) turn away their Wives, and keep Wenches? at least, those that are so civil to live with a Wise, maintain a Mistriss beside.

sp.speaker: Lov.
sp.p: And if it be not true, why do the great Debauchées at last, forsake all their Mistresses for a Wife? we find most of 'em Marry at the long run; nay generally they prove the best Husbands. The Reason is, they have experimented the folly of that lewd course of Life.

sp.speaker: Carl.
sp.p: I had never so good an Opinion of Marriage as now, for this Dog trick; these two jilting Jades show'd me, in leaving us so in the lurch, has lessen'd 'em in my esteem, to the degree of honest Women, and now the scales are even, the first of either party that obliges me, draws it down on that side.

sp.speaker: Lov.
sp.p: Than Hillaria I hope, will turn the ballance.

sp.speaker: Carel.
sp.p: If the Devil is minded to loose a Gamster, let him venter to make her and me Friends.

sp.speaker: Lov.
sp.p: And he will, for here she comes to work your Conversion for which end, i'll leave you together. Ex. Lovel

sp.speaker: Hil.
sp.p: How now Gallant? Careless Sings and walks about, as not much minding her.

sp.speaker: Carel
sp.p: O Madam!—

sp.speaker: Hil.
sp.p: You are very merry Gallant.

sp.speaker: Carel.
sp.p: I have no Reason to be otherwise. Sings and walks about 2 or three times, and jostle one another. Why do you jostle me?—

sp.speaker: Hil.
sp.p: And why do you jostle me?

sp.speaker: Carel.
sp.p: You walk in my way.

sp.speaker: Hil.
sp.p: 'Tis you walk in mine.

sp.speaker: Carel.
sp.p: Get farther off.

sp.speaker: Hil.
sp.p: Go you farther off.

sp.speaker: Carel.
sp.p: I was here first.

sp.speaker: Hil.
sp.p: Than you may begon first.

sp.speaker: Carel.
sp.p: I have business here.

sp.speaker: Hil.
sp.p: What, to see me?

sp.speaker: Carel.
sp.p: No, with Mr. Lovell.

sp.speaker: Hil.
sp.p: Yes in my Conscience, you was coming to see me.

sp.speaker: Carel.
sp.p: Now I think on't, so I was on purpose, to let you know that I am alive; for I believe you thought, I had either Hang'd my self for the trick you put on me, or had broke my Heart, with sighing for your absence, with whom I am so desperate in Love▪ but believe me, I have not yet broke so much as a button, and may I break my Neck when I do, either for Love of you, or any Woman living.

sp.speaker: Hil.
sp.p: Yet Spark you love me.

sp.speaker: Carel.
sp.p: 'Tis true, I love you well enough; because you are unlucky; and was not honesty in the case, I should love you better, but as it is, you are in a desperate condition.

sp.speaker: Hil.
sp.p: Must I than despair?

sp.speaker: Carel.
sp.p: You are for Matrimony, and that I hate, I can no more endure a Wife, than a standing Dish of Meat.

sp.speaker: Hil.
sp.p: You think than I am in Love with you.

sp.speaker: Carel.
sp.p: Think it! ha, ha,— as thô I did not know that, by your following me, up and down, what came you for after me? and for what come you to talk with me now, if you an't in Love with me? and what made you seduce the Woman from me, but that you might have me all to your self.

sp.speaker: Hil.
sp.p: I vow now you put me in mind on't, I may be in Love with you; but you say my case is desperate, then desperate must be the Cure, and I must e'en resolve to be your Mistress, Wench, or what you'll call't.

sp.speaker: Carel.
sp.p: That's your only Remedy— I am a Bird of Prey, and fly at all.

sp.speaker: Hil.
sp.p: Nay than I am a Dead Woman still, for you'll soon take a flight from me to another.

sp.speaker: Carel.
sp.p: But when I have catch'd my prey, I take my Belly full of it; I never leave it till I am gorg'd.

sp.speaker: Hil.
sp.p: And will your Stomach come again.

sp.speaker: Carel.
sp.p: Yes, sometimes, but generally some ravenous Fowl or another, picks up my leavings, and flies away with't.

sp.speaker: Hil.
sp.p: But wou'd you have no more care of me.

sp.speaker: Carel.
sp.p: My care would signifie but little; for a Man seldome finds either Money or a Woman, in the same place he left 'em

sp.speaker: Hil.
sp.p: But is it not a point of Honour amongst you Men, not to leave the Women you debauch, but if they prove Constant, to provide for 'em.

sp.speaker: Carel.
sp.p: Provide for 'em! is it not enough we teach 'em a Trade, by which they may get their livings. But you will not want providing for, you have a good Portion, but if I wou'd, you your self in a short time would be for change.

sp.speaker: Hil.
sp.p: Well Careless, we'll do nothing rashly, I'll to Bed and consult with my Pillow, and to morrow tell you more of my mind.

sp.speaker: Carel.
sp.p: But let me give you this caution, be not deceived with the vain considerations of Virtue, Modesty, Chastity, Honour, Reputaion, and the like, these are Bugg-words, that aw'd Women in former Ages, and still fool a great many in this. And if once these idle notions get into your thoughts, I shall give you o'er for a lost Woman.

sp.speaker: Hil.
sp.p: The common practice of my Sex, may prevail much; evil example makes twenty Sinners to the black Gentleman's one. Adieu.

sp.speaker: Carel.
sp.p: So much for her, Captain, how is't with you, you look as if you were not well.

sp.speaker: Capt.
sp.p: I am not, I have a wild Fire in my Veins, my blood is a circulating flame, it spouts against the upper Region of my brain, like a tempestuous Hurricane.

sp.speaker: Carel.
sp.p: By your description this should be Love; that's the disease torments you; Love plays mad wreaks, when first it enters a breast and finds resistance.

sp.speaker: Capt.
sp.p: Love!

sp.speaker: Carel.
sp.p: Yes, Love like the small Pox, as any seldome escape it, so the more dangerous it is, when it comes late.

sp.speaker: Capt.
sp.p: I don't know, but I have had strange turmoyls and combustions in my fancy e'er since your friend gave me that description, and show'd me the Lady; I have been looking for her.

sp.speaker: Carel.
sp.p: See she's under sail, she'll be up with you presently.

sp.speaker: Arab.
sp.p: Captain,— what execution have my Eyes done— are you in Love yet?

sp.speaker: Capt.
sp.p: You have fir'd your upper Teer, you have pepper'd me with small shot.

sp.speaker: Carl.
sp.p: Yes, Madam, he's furiously infected with Love, but can you tell him how to cure his Disease.

sp.speaker: Arab.
sp.p: To cure Love, he must look for Love again.

sp.speaker: Carel.
sp.p: There's incouragement for you— bear up close, speak to her Captain.

sp.speaker: Capt.
sp.p: I could speak better to the great Guns of an Armada, whose Oratory is nothing but Fire and noyse.

sp.speaker: Carel.
sp.p: Board her to rights, briskly.

sp.speaker: Capt.
sp.p: If I was but once master of her Forecastle.

sp.speaker: Carel.
sp.p: That's easy, she's leaky Captain,— she's leaky.

sp.speaker: Capt.
sp.p: Than she'll founder anon.

sp.speaker: Carel.
sp.p: Madam, afford him your hand; so now I have brought you to grapling, I'll vere off, and give you Sea room, get clear of one another as you can. Ex. Carel.

sp.speaker: Capt.
sp.p: Can you Love?

sp.speaker: Arab.
sp.p: Yes Captain.

sp.speaker: Capt.
sp.p: Me; by the North Star, say but that word, and this Sword, if you command, shall Unpeole half the World, Draws his Sword. to give us and our Progeny Elbow-room. Discharge but that word from your Mouth, and Command me to still Tempests, to split Rocks in a sunder. Lady, do but feel the weight on't; see is't not an excellent blade?

sp.speaker: Arab.
sp.p: I have no great skill.

sp.speaker: Capt.
sp.p: Feel, has it not a brave edge, and what a point is here!

sp.speaker: Arab.
sp.p: 'Tis dangerous medling with edge Tools, pray put it up.

sp.speaker: Capt.
sp.p: Have you any Enemies? if you have—

sp.speaker: Arab.
sp.p: No Captain, put it up.

sp.speaker: Capt.
sp.p: Will you Love me then?

sp.speaker: Arab.
sp.p: I Love not danger; any thing but killing.

sp.speaker: Capt.
sp.p: Did you never see one kill'd?

sp.speaker: Arab.
sp.p: No.

sp.speaker: Capt.
sp.p: No! had you but been with me in our last Engagement, you might have seen a sight, that would have made a Coward in love with Death. There you'd have seen our Enemies bear up in a half Moon, exposing to our view, the terror of their wooden Castles, the Mouths of their great Guns, which were made to swallow Iron Morsels, that might lie heavy upon their Stomachs, till they were disgorg'd in our Faces.

sp.speaker: Arab.
sp.p: Fau— fau—

sp.speaker: Capt.
sp.p:
We, with Topsails out, Flags and Streamers flourishing in the Wind, and Trumpets sounding, unite our force; than like Thunder
fall in amongst them; there like the Sons of Terrour, we are seen in Clouds of Fire and Smoak, The Slaughter now begins—

sp.speaker: Arab.
sp.p: Hold good Captain.

sp.speaker: Capt.
sp.p: We play at Tennis with Iron balls, and Death comes whisting by our Ears, Heads take Fire in their Brain pans, and burst in sunder like Granadoes, scattering the wild Fire of their Brains in their fellow Soldiers Faces.

sp.speaker: Arab.
sp.p: You fright me horribly.

sp.speaker: Capt.
sp.p: Other Heads, fly from one Ship with the Bullets that saluted them, to visit their friends in another. Limbs like Langrel-Shot, mount, scattering in the Air, and hands that could not reach their Enemies before, now flie into distant Vessels, to give their Foes a box o'the Ear; other hands grasping their Swords, clear a whole Deck in their flight.

sp.speaker: Arab.
sp.p: What shall I do!

sp.speaker: Capt.
sp.p: We are now in a confusion, the Fire-ships flame, and their half Moon is divided— into blazing Stars.

sp.speaker: Arab.
sp.p: O quarter, Captain, quarter!

sp.speaker: Arab.
sp.p: Some burn, the Men leap over board, and drown themselves to save their lives; other Ships real drunk, with the Sea brine, and at last sink to the bottom, to follow these brave Men, who fought in 'em, with as much Courage, as they drank.

sp.speaker: Arab.
sp.p: Have you yet done?

sp.speaker: Capt.
sp.p: The Flags and Pendants.

sp.speaker: Arab.
sp.p: Yet more—

sp.speaker: Capt.
sp.p: That hung wantonly playing in the Air, now on the Decks lie stian'd in blood, and their tant Masts are brought by the Board, and lie on their Hull 's as in Coffins.— how like you it, is't not brave?

sp.speaker: Arab.
sp.p: I am almost Dead with fear.

sp.speaker: Capt.
sp.p: I thought you valiant; did not I see you draw your Sword.

sp.speaker: Arab.
sp.p: In Land matters I am Couragious, but in Sea affairs a meer Coward; their very terms are Bullets to me, I would not hear such another relation—

sp.speaker: Capt.
sp.p: Not hear! can you fear when I stand by? my voice is gentle, but I have somthing that can speak lowder to your Enemies, see—

sp.speaker: Arab.
sp.p: What's that, a Pistol? Captain shows a Pistol.

sp.speaker: Capt.
sp.p: 'Tis the spawn of a Cannon, a little spit-Fire Devil.

sp.speaker: Arab.
sp.p: Pray Conjure him down again.

sp.speaker: Capt.
sp.p: Frighted at my voice! you shall hear what a brave Language this speaks. Captain cocks it, and shiots it off as he goes out, and just as Sir Bar. enters.

div.head: SCENE VI.
div.stage: Enter Sir Barnaby, in an extravagant Night dress. Sir Barnaby looking in, Arab. runs off squeaking. Captain shoots off the Pistol just by Sir Barnaby, who falls down.

sp.speaker: Sir Bar.
sp.p: What noise is this?

sp.speaker: Arab.
sp.p: Ah!

sp.speaker: Capt.
sp.p: Gon— I'll after her, and give her t'other salute.

sp.speaker: Sir Bar.
sp.p: Murder— murder, help.

sp.speaker: Dash.
sp.p: Oh! Sir, what's the matter?

sp.speaker: Sir Bar.
sp.p: I am shot, I am shot.

sp.speaker: Dash.
sp.p: Shot Sir!

sp.speaker: Sir Bar.
sp.p: I am shot, as sure as a Gun, I am shot.

sp.speaker: Dash.
sp.p: I don't see you bleed.

sp.speaker: Sir Bar.
sp.p: It may be the Bullet stops the hole, and won't let the blood come out.

sp.speaker: Dash.
sp.p: Shall I run for a Surgeon—

sp.speaker: Sir Bar.
sp.p: But where, All is not in hand, that helps. Look honest Dash, and see what I ail.

sp.speaker: Dash.
sp.p: Please your Worship to stand up—

sp.speaker: Sir Bar.
sp.p: What! before I know whether I am kill'd or not.

sp.speaker: Dash.
sp.p: I see no signs on't— do you feel any hurt, do you think you are kill'd?

sp.speaker: Sir Bar.
sp.p: Dash. I think I don't feel any, but Thoughts are deceitful; look, look, The Stander by sees more than a Gamester.

sp.speaker: Dash.
sp.p: It has miss'd you, Sir.

sp.speaker: Sir Bar.
sp.p: Then a Blot's no Blot till it he hit. I durst have sworn I had been kill'd, for he shot me down as flat as a Flounder: But all is not lost that's in Danger. And give a Man Luck and throw him into the Sea.

sp.speaker: Dash.
sp.p: Did your Worship see no Body?

sp.speaker: Sir Bar.
sp.p: Who e'er it was, they thought One pair of heel's worth two pair of Hands; they ran for't, As if the Devil drove 'em.

sp.speaker: Dash.
sp.p: Will not your Worship follow 'em.

sp.speaker: Sir Bar.
sp.p: Let 'em go, Make a golden Bridge for a flying Enemy. 'Tis Wisdom to keep out of harms way. Take the Candle, let's see if all be safe here, and that the noise has not waken'd Jacinta, then we'll to Bed again.— Ha— her Door is open— what can the meaning be at this time of Night— Dash, look in and see, if any body be there, whilst I compose my self— hum— hum— I had like to have Paid for my peeping.

sp.speaker: Dash.
sp.p: No Sir— there's no body. Dash. with the Candle goes in

sp.speaker: Sir Bar.
sp.p: It's good to be sure, let's us go in then, Seeing is believing.

div.head: SCENE VII.
div.stage: Enter Justice Greedy, in Night-geer, Mrs. Breeder, Mrs. Dazie, half undrest, he peeping in first, as from his Chamber

sp.speaker: Greed.
sp.p: Surely I heard talking— but als whist— Here, here, you may venter out.

sp.speaker: Breed.
sp.p: Is any body stirring.

sp.speaker: Greed.
sp.p: Not a Mouse—

sp.speaker: Dazie.
sp.p: I heard a noise e'er since we went to Bed.

sp.speaker: Breed.
sp.p: So did I.

sp.speaker: Greed.
sp.p: It may be the Cook is stirring— I charg'd him to call me before day, for I am Overseer general of the Kitchin, besides my Stomachs up, and I can lie a Bed no longer.

sp.speaker: Breed.
sp.p: I swear, Mr. Justice, I shall have a better Opinion of a Man that has a good Stomach, as long as I live, for your sake.

sp.speaker: Greed.
sp.p: Ay, ay, Good at Meat, good at Work.

sp.speaker: Dazie.
sp.p: You are a brisk old blade, to venter on two at once.

sp.speaker: Greed.
sp.p: I begin to grow Old, but the time was, when I cou'd have been froliksome with two and two, my Girls— but hark, the House is up— I hear the chopping Knives at work upon the Dressers— they'll be coming to call me— slip down stairs and get into some by Room, and make your selves ready there.

sp.speaker: Dazie.
sp.p: I see light at the bottom of the stairs, we can't go down yet without being seen.

sp.speaker: Breed.
sp.p: Than we'll in here again.

sp.speaker: Greed.
sp.p: No, no, here, I feel a door open— this is some room that no body lies in.

sp.speaker: Dazie.
sp.p: Where—

sp.speaker: Greed.
sp.p: Here— here— In— in— so— now I'll into my Chamber, make my self ready, Greedy put them two into Sir Barnaby's room, in the dark. and Eat a good Breakfast, a quart or two of good Egg Caudle, will be a necessary recruit after this nights undertaking— Ah Whores, brisk dainty Whores. Greed. Exit.

sp.speaker: Sir Bar.
sp.p: Ah Madam Jacinta! is it so, out of your Bed at this time of Night.

sp.speaker: Dash.
sp.p: O Lord, Sir, there's another random shot. A Gun goes off without, and a loud squeak.

sp.speaker: Sir Bar.
sp.p: We'll retire into our Castle then— They both retire into Jacint. Chamber. and keep out of harms way. Forewarn'd, Fore-arm'd.

div.head: SCENE IX.
div.stage: Enter Arabella running, followed by the Captain, holding a Pistol in his Hand, which he puts in his Coat-pocket. Careless, Lovell, Hilaria, Jacinta.

sp.speaker: Arab.
sp.p: Ah—

sp.speaker: Capt.
sp.p: Sure she'll love me anon.

sp.speaker: Carel.
sp.p: I told you Madam, you should see sport.

sp.speaker: Jac.
sp.p: How you tremble Madam!

sp.speaker: Arab.
sp.p: O the Captain's in his hot▪ fit, and I am in my cold?

sp.speaker: Hil.
sp.p: What has he done to you?

sp.speaker: Arab.
sp.p: Frighted me horribly; he has not spoke a word, but was as terrible, as the roaring of Cannon.

sp.speaker: Jac.
sp.p: The Captain wou'd be a rare Physician to cure Ladies of the Ague— if fighting 'em can do't.

sp.speaker: Lov.
sp.p: What was you doing Captain.

sp.speaker: Carel.
sp.p: Only saluting his Mistress.

sp.speaker: Capt.
sp.p: Right, I gave her a Gun, that's Sea Courtship.

sp.speaker: Lov.
sp.p: Your complement was very loud— you shou'd first have given her a fair summons to surrender, and seen if she'd have yielded upon Parley. Did you think to take her Heart by storm, as Man do Towns?

sp.speaker: Capt.
sp.p: It was more like a Souldier.

sp.speaker: Carel.
sp.p: But not like a Lover, Love is a gentle passion— but Madam, admit him again into your service— he will forget he is a Soldier, and turn Courtier for your sake.

sp.speaker: Arab.
sp.p: No, let him still retain his valour, but not express his Love, in such terrible Rhetorick.

sp.speaker: Capt.
sp.p: I know not how to Court you in a Silken phrase, but if down right reallity will do it, I'll be your friend both board and larboard.

sp.speaker: Arab.
sp.p: Than Captain, out with all your Sails, top and top-gallant, you shall be my Lover.

sp.speaker: Hil.
sp.p: Well perform'd, Madam.

sp.speaker: Arab.
sp.l: Whil'st I my Heart under your conduct steer,
No Coasting Pyrate, Lovers I, nor Rovers fear.

sp.speaker: Hil.
sp.p: Well, now Lovers I think 'tis time for you all to be at rest, but my Couzen here, I pity at my Heart, to morrow is her execution day, and I dare swear, she had rather 'twere for Hanging, than Marrying.

sp.speaker: Jac.
sp.p: O Hillaria! that word has damp'd all my mirth, I had else gone to Bed again, with some pleasure, for the Captains courtship had quite put to morrow out of my thoughts. But 'tis late— I'll bury my cares in my Pillow— and trust all to providence.

sp.speaker: Hil.
sp.p: I'll bear you company this Night as a friend do's an acquaintance, that's to be trust up the next morning; and all the time we can't sleep, we'll Sing no other Letany, than— From an old overgrown Looby, and from Sir Barnaby Booby— goodness deliver thee. Good night Servant—

sp.speaker: Carel.
sp.p: Good night, unluckiness. Exeunt Jacinta, and Hilaria, into their Chambers. Exeunt Lovell, Arabella, at another Door.

sp.speaker: Lov.
sp.p: Arabella, I'll see you to your Chamher.

sp.speaker: Arab.
sp.p: Good night Gentlemen.

sp.speaker: Capt.
sp.p: Bonos noches, bonos noches. I think it's now time for us to turn in too. As soon as Jacinta and Hilaria went off, they return back squeaking, as frighted.

sp.speaker: Carel.
sp.p: But now I think on't, what's become of our two Whores, must we give 'em o'er so.

div.head: SCENE X.
div.stage: Enter Sir Barnaby, with a Man's Suit of Cloaths in his Hand, and Dash.

sp.speaker: Jac. Hil.
sp.p: Ah— ah—

sp.speaker: Sir Bar.
sp.p: Your Whores Gentlemen! here are your Whores.

sp.speaker: Jac.
sp.p: How Sir Barnaby!

sp.speaker: Sir Bar.
sp.p: Ha, Madam Jacinta— I find you are a Canary-bird— out of your Nest, at this time of Night.

sp.speaker: Hil.
sp.p: Whores, said the Beast.

sp.speaker: Sir Bar.
sp.p: No better nor no worse, are these trappings fit for a Ladies Chamber? there has bren Rantum scantum doings within, the Bed's turn'd Topsy Turvy, Men's Cloathes and Women's, thrown Higeldy Pigeldy; whilst some are at it, Helter skelter, arsy versy, hand over head, and the Devil and all.

sp.speaker: Capt.
sp.p: What a Pox is all this— I am a shark, if I understand one syllable of what he sayes.

sp.speaker: Carel.
sp.p: Sir Barnaby, is this fit language for you to give Ladies, in Gentlemens Company?

sp.speaker: Capt.
sp.p: What does he affront the Ladies— have at his main-top— I'll shatter his Tackling. Captain draws.

sp.speaker: Carel.
sp.p: Hold Captain—

sp.speaker: Greed.
sp.p: What's here? Civil Wars, and homebred Combustions— keep the Peace.

sp.speaker: Carel.
sp.p: Put up Captain.

sp.speaker: Duz.
sp.p: Affront the Ladies— I'll rake him from stem to stern.

sp.speaker: Greed.
sp.p: Keep the Peace in the King's name.

sp.speaker: Carel.
sp.p: Forbear—

sp.speaker: Greed.
sp.p: Sir Barnaby, what's the matter?

sp.speaker: Sir Bar.
sp.p: The matter is, that Old Birds won't be caught with Chaff. Mr. Alderman, I thank you for your fine Daughter; but you shan't find, Sir Barnaby, the Man you take him for, Some wiser than some. Yet: And you Mrs. Jacinta, that look'd As harmless as a Devil of two Years old; and As demure, as if Butter would not melt in your Mouth, were you to be Married in the Morning, and could not forbear playing at leap frog o'er Night. Your servant, your servant—

sp.speaker: Greed.
sp.p: Hold, Sir Barnaby, a word with you, Sir Barnaby. Dash. Ex.

sp.speaker: Carel.
sp.p: If this should fall out so luckily now to Greed. runs after Sir Barnaby. break of the match.

sp.speaker: Hil.
sp.p: With a little good management it may.

sp.speaker: Carel.
sp.p: We'll all help it forward.

sp.speaker: Greed.
sp.p: O— O—

div.head: SCENE XII.
div.stage: Enter Sir Barnaby, Mrs. Breeder, and Dazie. Sir Barnaby goes off as to his Chamber, and turns back hastily, and o'erthrows the Justice that was running in after him.

sp.speaker: Sir Bar.
sp.p: Whose there— whos's there—

sp.speaker: Breed.
sp.p: Sir Barnaby, Sir Barnaby.

sp.speaker: Dazie.
sp.p: Sir Barnaby, Sir Barnaby.

sp.speaker: Carel.
sp.p: What's here, new discoveries.

sp.speaker: Dazie.
sp.p: Sir Barnaby, what makes you flie from us.

sp.speaker: Breed.
sp.p: What made you Sir Barnaby rise so early, and leave us in Bed by our selves?

sp.speaker: Greed.
sp.p: Rare Whores— strike that nail home. Greed. aside to the Whores.

sp.speaker: Sir Bar.
sp.p: Whores— Jades— Carrions—

sp.speaker: Hil.
sp.p: In my Conscience, Sir Barnaby has pick'd up your two Mistresses.

sp.speaker: Dazie.
sp.p: Gentlemen, You beat the bush, and he catch'd the birds.

sp.speaker: Breed.
sp.p: Ladies, you see old Love cannot be soon forgot.

sp.speaker: Sir Bar.
sp.p: Queans— Gypses— Baggages—

sp.speaker: Dazie.
sp.p: Sir Barnaby, Madam,— had not disown'd us last night, but that it was upon his Marriage, and before you.

sp.speaker: Sir Bar.
sp.p: Ye Harlots— ye— Strumpets— I'll have you whip'd and flead.

sp.speaker: Greed.
sp.p: O that's too much Sir Barnaby,— you have given 'em Correction already.

sp.speaker: Carel.
sp.p: What, Sir Barnaby, in Bed with two at once— Higledy Pigledy.

sp.speaker: Jac.
sp.p: No better,— nor no worse—

sp.speaker: Capt.
sp.p: Was this his rantum scantum.

sp.speaker: Hil.
sp.p: To be Marry'd in the Morning— Sir Barnaby and play at leap frog o'er night.

sp.speaker: Omn.
sp.p: Ha, ha, ha.

sp.speaker: Sir Bar.
sp.p: Rest you merry, Let them laugh that win. Hey Chamberlain, Chamberlain— Dash, call to the Hostler, bid him saddle my Horse, and let the Boot-catcher bring up my Boots, I'll begon at peep of Day.

sp.speaker: Dash.
sp.p: Yes, and please your Worship. Sir Barnaby Exit.

sp.speaker: Greed.
sp.p: Hold Sir Barnaby, be not in such hast.

sp.speaker: Carel.
sp.p: Let him go— let him go.

sp.speaker: Greed.
sp.p: No, that must not be— his going may spoyl a good Dinner, at least, I'll perswade him not to go till he has Din'd.
Well, you luscious Jades you— I'll remember your Christmas boxes for saving my credit so handsomly— get you down into the Larder, I'll give you a rare Breakfast. Ex. Greed.

sp.speaker: Breed.
sp.p: We'll meet you there— your Servant Ladies.

sp.speaker: Dazie.
sp.p: Your Servant Gentlemen Breed. and Dazie. Exeunt.

sp.speaker: Carel.
sp.p: Look you Madam— who would not Love such honest wenches— how ready they were to do a Man a good turn.

sp.speaker: Hil.
sp.p: Servant! I'll allow they have a great deal of good nature— for they are for doing every Man's turn as well as yours.

sp.speaker: Carel.
sp.p: That's Malice, and ill nature in you—

sp.speaker: Hil.
sp.p: I'll grant you any thing at this time, because we'll not loose the opportunity of doing my Couzen a piece of service.

sp.speaker: Carel.
sp.p: We'll find out Lovell— tell him the whole business, and concert with him, how matters shall be manag'd.

sp.speaker: Jac.
sp.p: In the mean time, we'll retire into our Chamber.

sp.speaker: Hil.
sp.p: Let that be the place of Rendezvouse.

sp.speaker: Carel.
sp.p: Come Captain. Careless, Captain, Exeunt together. Jacinta, Hilaria, another way Exeunt

div.head: SCENE I.
div.stage: Enter Sir Barnaby, Mr. Alderman Furr.

sp.speaker: Sir Bar.
sp.p: THen you heard nothing of all these fine doings last Night▪

sp.speaker: Fur.
sp.p: No, Sir.

sp.speaker: Sir Bar.
sp.p: Nor you did not hear the Pistol go off?

sp.speaker: Ald.
sp.p: No.

sp.speaker: Sir Bar.
sp.p: Lady, you slept like a Dormouse, and I wonder that you being so sound a sleeper— your Daughter shou'd be so wakeful to leave her Bed at midnight.

sp.speaker: Fur.
sp.p: But Sir Barnaby, are you not mistaken in what you told me.

sp.speaker: Sir Bar.
sp.p: Look you Sir, Truth may be blam'd, but never sham'd. I cou'd give you farther proof if occasion serv'd. But Truth is not to spoken at all times.

sp.speaker: Ald.
sp.p: Yet it concerns you to speak, and to prove what you speak, this is no jesting matter.

sp.speaker: Sir Bar.
sp.p: Well than, O'er shooes, o'er boots. And In for a Penny, in for a Pound. Whee— ho— Toby. Sir Bar. whistles for Toby.

sp.speaker: Toby.
sp.p: Here, Sir.

sp.speaker: Greed.
sp.p: I'll resign my Office, I'll resign my Office.

sp.speaker: Fur.
sp.p: What now!

sp.speaker: Greed.
sp.p: I'll resign my Office, if I been't better obey'd.

sp.speaker: Fur.
sp.p: What, are you frantick?

sp.speaker: Greed.
sp.p:
'Twould make me frantick, and stark mad, were not I a Justice of Peace, and Coram too, which this rebellious Cook cares not a
straw for; there are a dozen of Woodcocks.

sp.speaker: Fur.
sp.p: Pray put your self into the number, and make 'em a Baker's dozen.

sp.speaker: Greed.
sp.p: I am contented, so they may be drest to my mind; he has found out a new device for sawce, and won't dress them with Toasts and Butter. I had rather loose my Commission, than suffer't.

sp.speaker: Fur.
sp.p: Let 'em be drest as you will, go in and trouble us no farther.

sp.speaker: Greed.
sp.p: Well, I'll go, Woodcocks without Toasts and Butter, by the Lord Harry, I'll ne'er suffer't. Greed. Ex.

sp.speaker: Sir Bar.
sp.p: Now Toby, speak neither for favour nor affection, But tell truth, and shame the Devil, what did you tell me you saw last Night?

sp.speaker: Toby.
sp.p: Having occasion to rise in the Night, to go down (and please your Worship,) as I came in again, I perceived two young brisk Sparks Dance up stairs before me, they parted in the Gallery, and one of 'em went tap, tap, at Mrs. Jacinta's door, which presently open'd, and in he went. Thought I, this is some guest that has mistaken his Room— I crept softly, and peep'd in— whip went of his Hat— and whip went off his Coat— thus half undress'd threw himself within the Curtains, and cry'd, my Dear— Dear Jacinta; and there they hug'd and kiss'd, and hug'd— till the Bed shook like an old barn, in a windy day.

sp.speaker: Sir Bar.
sp.p: Hum!

sp.speaker: Tob.
sp.p: At length says Mrs. Jacinta (whose voice I knew,) come, come, to Bed my Dear, and don't get Cold; so I will reply'd t'other, wee'll so kiss and hug all this Night, my Dear, Dear, for you are to be Marryed to Morrow.

sp.speaker: Sir Bar.
sp.p: And— and what followed?

sp.speaker: Tob.
sp.p: Then the door was lock'd on the inside. I sat me down, resolv'd to watch till Morning— but before day light, out they came, and surprising me there, took me for a Spy, and a listner, and discharged a Pistol at me, just as my Master open'd his door it mist me, down stairs I scatter'd, they after me— but I ran into the Orchard, and hid my self in the Pear-tree.

sp.speaker: Sir Bar.
sp.p: Hang him that has ne'er a shift.

sp.speaker: Fur.
sp.p: And you both heard and saw a Man in my Daughter's Chamber.

sp.speaker: Tob.
sp.p: As I told you, upon my Corporal Oath.

sp.speaker: Fur.
sp.p: But—

sp.speaker: Greed.
sp.p: Well, never was the like of such a fellow.

sp.speaker: Fur.
sp.p: Are you interrupting us again!

sp.speaker: Greed.
sp.p: Mr. Alderman, what do you think?

sp.speaker: Fur.
sp.p: I think, you'll do very well to be gone.

sp.speaker: Greed.
sp.p: Nay, but pray hear me—

sp.speaker: Fur.
sp.p: I will hear nothing.

sp.speaker: Greed.
sp.p: Well then— I take your silence for consent, I'll e'en commit this sawcy Cook. I'll sign a Warrant for him forthwith.

sp.speaker: Fur.
sp.p: Let me tell you Mr. Justice you do very ill to trouble us, when we are upon serious business?

sp.speaker: Greed.
sp.p: Why, Mr. Alderman, there's as lovely a Codds-head, as ever Eyes beheld, and how do you think this Rogue of a Cook is going to dress it.

sp.speaker: Fur.
sp.p: As he shou'd do your Head, cleave it, and take out the brains.

sp.speaker: Greed.
sp.p: What's the matter Mr. Alderman, you are e'en as Chollerick as the Cook? what say you Sir Barnaby— will it do well— a Cods-head without Shrimps.

sp.speaker: Sir Bar.
sp.p: Sir, We have other Fish to fry at this time. You had as good go from whence you came, for here you will be but Out of the Frying-pan, into the Fire.

sp.speaker: Greed.
sp.p: Well, I'll try t'other bout with the Cook, and if I can't fadge, I'll discreetly sit me down and cry for vexation, for my passion must have vent— a Cods head without Shrimps, O monstrous!

sp.speaker: Fur.
sp.p: Friend, what manner of Man was this person, you saw in my Daughter's Chamber. Greedy Exit.

sp.speaker: Tob.
sp.p: I did not see his Face— for his back was to the Door all the while— but a brisk youngster i'saith.

sp.speaker: Sir Bar.
sp.p: Now I have given you sufficient proof, restore my acquittance, and take back your Daughter— Even Reckoning, makes long Friends. And so Merry meet, merry part.

sp.speaker: Fur.
sp.p: I'll give one Proverb for your two, One tales good, till another is told. Therefore I'll not close my account with you, till I have spoken with my Daughter.

sp.speaker: Sir Bar.
sp.p: You have paid me in my own Coyn. Reason is Reason, all the World over. For he that Judges, must hear both parties. But pray dispatch, for I stand upon Thorns.

sp.speaker: Fur.
sp.p: It will be necessary, that you, who are her accusers, shou'd go with me to her.

sp.speaker: Sir Bar.
sp.p: A guilty Conscience needs no accuser, however we'll go, thô we Shall be as welcome, as Water into a Ship, for I know she'll look at us, As the Devil looks over Lincoln. Exeunt.

sp.speaker: Greed.
sp.p: No Shrimps! a Cods-head without Shrimps!

sp.speaker: Cook.
sp.p: Yes, Sir, a Cods head without Shrimps, is as good as a Justices head, without Brains.

sp.speaker: Greed.
sp.p: I tell you Cook, you are sawcy.

sp.speaker: Cook.
sp.p: I tell you Mr. Justice, you are Jack in an Office.

sp.speaker: Greed.
sp.p: I shall lay you by the Heels.

sp.speaker: Cook.
sp.p: Than, I Jack Sawce, the Cook, will bast your Worship, as I bast my Meat.

sp.speaker: Greed.
sp.p: To strike a Justice of Peace, is Petty Treason, Edwardi quinto. But for spoyling of Dinner, I'd send you away presently, and commit you without Bail or Mainprize.

sp.speaker: Cook.
sp.p: For all that— keep out of the Kitchin, which is my Dominion, or I will scall'd you without measure, and without mercy. Why sure Mr. Justice, I can dress Dinner without you, hau—

sp.speaker: Greed.
sp.p: The Rogues as Chollerick as a rosting Lobster— I must give him good words, or All the fat will be in the Fire. Well honest Jack Sawce, do as thou wilt— why should old Friends fall out— give me thy hand.

sp.speaker: Cook.
sp.p: I Love your Worship with all my Heart.

sp.speaker: Greed.
sp.p: Dost thou? prethee than let there be Shrimps to the Cods head— dear Sawce, honest dear Sawce.

sp.speaker: Cook.
sp.p: Why▪ so there is Sir—

sp.speaker: Greed.
sp.p: Is there— what made you and I quarrel then?

sp.speaker: Cook.
sp.p: You wou'd not have patience till it came to the Table.

sp.speaker: Greed.
sp.p: Thou say'd true— come prithee let's go see how matters are in the Kitchen.

sp.speaker: Cook.
sp.p: Kitchen me no Kitchen, if you can be quiet, things will be done well enough.

sp.speaker: Greed.
sp.p: Give me thy hand once more— thou art an honest Fellow,— thou sayst there shall be Shrimps than, ha, shall there?

sp.speaker: Cook.
sp.p: If you speak Sir, one word more—

sp.speaker: Greed.
sp.p: I— a— done— I'll bring thee a bottle of Sack into the Kitchen.

sp.speaker: Cook.
sp.p: And I'll relish't with a plate of pickled Mushrooms.

sp.speaker: Greed.
sp.p: Honest Cook! honest Jack Sawce, no Shrimps! in my Conscience, 'twould have broke my Heart. Exeunt.

div.head: SCENE III.
div.stage: Enter Lovell; Captain, a little after.

sp.speaker: Lov.
sp.p: So far all goes well, my Brother resolves to quit the Field— but now to work the Alderman— that he may not suspect a Contrivance, that's the difficulty— let me see—

sp.speaker: Capt.
sp.p: Mr. Lovell! yes, 'tis he— soho— whos's within?

sp.speaker: Lov.
sp.p: Are you here Captain! Lov. stands as in a study, Captain enters.

sp.speaker: Capt.
sp.p: That's a Lovers question right— e'en let your Goes up to him and knocks at his Breast as at a Door. Eyes answer you— but I thought you had not been at home. Your body look'd, as if had been forsaken by your Soul. Whirlwinds take this Love, it has— made a fool of me too; when I am spoken too, I am thinking of Ladies; my witts and senses are gone a rambling, like Seamen gotten a shoar, in their long-boat.

sp.speaker: Lov.
sp.p: Your friend gave you fair warning not to fall in love.

sp.speaker: Capt.
sp.p: There's the Devil on't, I know not how it comes about— well, believe me, thô Women look like Angels— there's witchcraft about 'em; for if a Woman does but fetch the long heave, with lifting up her Head, and bending in her Back, two little— round— white— plump— pouting Devils pop up before, which put such a glowing heat into my veins, that my blood in a moment grows too hot for it's Chanels▪ and I could o'errun a score of 'em.

sp.speaker: Lov.
sp.p: You are transported at the very thoughts of Women.

sp.speaker: Capt.
sp.p:
I am now in one of my fits— that I had but half a dozen Ladies
in my great Cabin! how I'd rummage them together, I'd make 'em smoak again.

sp.speaker: Lov.
sp.p: If you are so hot, take a walk in the open Air to cool you.

sp.speaker: Capt.
sp.p: That won't do— if we were going to engage, perhaps the loss of a Leg or an Arm, might abate my Feaver.

sp.speaker: Lov,
sp.p: Your distemper is so rooted in you, that you must loose a Leg or an Arm for every handsome Woman you see, or you'll not be throughly cur'd.

sp.speaker: Capt.
sp.p: Say you so, than I'll endure it still, and try what time and chance will do.

sp.speaker: Lov.
sp.p: But how go squares 'twixt you and your Mistress?

sp.speaker: Capt.
sp.p: Well remembred, she sent me this Letter e'en now by her Maid; I wanted somebody to read it to me.

sp.speaker: Lov.
sp.p: Can't you Read?

sp.speaker: Capt.
sp.p: No, I am a Sea-Captain, the Sea breeds Soldiers, but not Schollars: 'tis out of my Element.

sp.speaker: Lov.
sp.p: You shall hear it then.

body.p: MY Roaring Boy, I can Love no longer at your fierce rate, my Heart is bound under another Convoy, give Chase to a fresh Mistress; I am sailing after a new Rigg'd Gallant, and now bid you defiance. So a boon Voyage to you Captain, and farewell.

sp.speaker: Capt.
sp.p: What, turn'd Renegate?

sp.speaker: Lov.
sp.p: Short warning this!

sp.speaker: Capt.
sp.p: See, she's not out of my Hemisphere. I'll give her Chase.

sp.speaker: Lov.
sp.p: They tack about to us.

sp.speaker: Arab
sp.p: How dejected my Lover looks now I have taken away his Commission.

sp.speaker: Hil.
sp.p: Captain, what think you of love?

sp.speaker: Capt.
sp.p: As of folly.

sp.speaker: Arab.
sp.p: Is't not a fine pastime?

sp.speaker: Capt.
sp.p: Yes for Fools.

sp.speaker: Arab.
sp.p: What think you of Women?

sp.speaker: Capt.
sp.p: As of light Sailors.

sp.speaker: Hil.
sp.p: Arab. Ha, ha, ha.

sp.speaker: Lov.
sp.p: That shot Captain, hit 'twixt wind and water.

sp.speaker: Capt.
sp.p: Or, as of Ships that are crank for want of Ballast, toss'd about with every wave, and cannot be steer'd in any true course?

sp.speaker: Arab.
sp.p: Hil. Ha, ha, ha.

sp.speaker: Capt.
sp.p: Do you play with my Anger; Am I so tame to be laugh'd at? sure I have seem'd more terrible, when with this Sword, I have lop'd off Limbs, strow'd Decks with Carcases, turn'd Fleets to floating Hospitals, sent Navies to their Ports to cut down Masts, and hew the Timber of their scatter'd Vessels into wooden Legs and Crutches, to under-prop the Cripples they brought home. Love, hast thou disarm'd my looks of Manhood?— phew— with that gale begone.

sp.speaker: Hil. Arab.
sp.p: Ha, ha, ha.

sp.speaker: Hil.
sp.p: Captain, Love is still in Port, he went not out with that strong puff.

sp.speaker: Lov.
sp.p: No, Love has not yet weigh'd Anchor.

sp.speaker: Arab.
sp.p: Captain— you have a qualm yet in your Stomach, you are either Sea-sick, or Love-sick still.

sp.speaker: Hil.
sp.p:
But Captain— if you have really done with Love and Women—
Let us know your thoughts of both in good earnest, what is Love?

sp.speaker: Capt.
sp.p: A Sea, a dangerous Sea, where Wind and Tide are still contrary: Men are the Barks that venture out, whose ruins still its Waves conspire.

sp.speaker: Arab.
sp.p: And what are Women in this Ocean?

sp.speaker: Capt.
sp.p: Pyrates, that rob us of our hearts, Laplanders that give us a fair wind to leave safe Harbors, and when we are out at Sea, make it swell to a Tempest to drown us. I have out-rid the Storm, thanks to my lusty Vessel, and now being gotten safe in Harbor, can look back and say— Yonder I had like to have been wreck'd.

sp.speaker: Lov.
sp.p: Well said, now you have given them a whole Broad-side.

sp.speaker: Arab.
sp.p: For all that, I see he's but a fresh-water Lover yet: Now you think your self past danger, you are in greatest peril to be Cast away— what think you if that Letter which rais'd this Tempest, was but a Plot to— see how my Lover cou'd bear the loss of his Mistress?

sp.speaker: Lov.
sp.p: What wind do you call this?— By what Point of the Compass will you steer now?

sp.speaker: Capt.
sp.p: I think I had best make what haste I can to come up with stern of her.

sp.speaker: Arab.
sp.p: That it was so, here's my hand on't. Arab. and Durzo takes hands.

sp.speaker: Hil.
sp.p: 'Tis very true, this Plot was but to try your humour.

sp.speaker: Capt.
sp.p: Why then, we'll put out to Sea once again, and my heart shall run the risque with yours in all Adventures.

sp.speaker: Arab.
sp.l: Captain, I strike sail to you.
You now with Triumph in Love's Ocean steer,
Calm is the Sea, and from all Pyrates clear.

sp.speaker: Lov.
sp.p: The Conference is broke up, here comes Careless and my Brother: Get you two in— Now Captain, for our management.

sp.speaker: Capt.
sp.p: Let him come. Arabella and Hilaria Exeunt▪

div.head: SCENE V.
div.stage: Enter Sir Barnaby, Careless and Furr.

sp.speaker: Sir Barn.
sp.p: You see your Daughter is so confounded at one Evidence, she scarcely had confidence to deny't; for a guilty Conscience needs no Accuser.

sp.speaker: Fur.
sp.p: I am sorry you had the trouble to come so far for so little purpose; but excuse me— I cannot forbear grieving at a Childs misfortune.

sp.speaker: Sir Barn.
sp.p: Children are certain Cares, but uncertain Comforts. Now, Sir, remember that Giff Gaff is an honest man; You have your Daughter, give me my Acquittance. So the man has his Mare again and no hurt done.

sp.speaker: Fur.
sp.p: 'Tis Lock'd up in my Chamber, but I'll fetch it you: To commit such extravagance the very Night before her marriage, what madness possest her!

sp.speaker: Carel.
sp.p: Sir Barnaby, you intend then to begon.

sp.speaker: Sir Barn.
sp.p: As soon as I can get my Boots on.

sp.speaker: Carel.
sp.p: Without marrying Mrs. Jacinta.

sp.speaker: Sir Barn.
sp.p: She has spun a fine thread; e'en let her brew as she bak'd.

sp.speaker: Carel.
sp.p: Who do you think shall marry her, now you have defam'd her?

sp.speaker: Sir Barn
sp.p: He that was with her last Night, if he please: Evening Orts are good Morning fother: but for my part, I am not so hungry to lick another man's dish.

sp.speaker: Carel.
sp.p:
But Sir Barnaby, you are the man must make her reparation, you
have traduc'd me and defam'd her— the scandal brings an aspersion on the whole Family that I seek to contract alliance with, for her Cozen Hilaria is the person I pretend marriage to; for all offences therefore against her— her Family and my self— from you I challenge satisfaction.

sp.speaker: Sir Barn.
sp.p: What do you mean by satisfaction?

sp.speaker: Carel.
sp.p: Here before your Brother and the Captain, I require that you first deny all you have said against the Lady's Honour. Secondly, that you make it your request to marry her.

sp.speaker: Sir Barn.
sp.p: Bate me an Ace of that, quoth Bolton.

sp.speaker: Carel.
sp.p: You must, Sir.

sp.speaker: Sir Barn.
sp.p: I have brought an old House upon my head; Eat my words and marry her. Two words to that bargain.

sp.speaker: Lov.
sp.p: No, Sir, the last I deny; thô I believe nothing in prejudice of Jacinta's Honour, how e'er unhappy circumstances make him think so, yet till he is convinc'd to the contrary, he cannot in Honour, nor must not Marry her.

sp.speaker: Capt.
sp.p: Must not!— he must, and shall or—

sp.speaker: Capt.
sp.p: I say must— unless I spring a Leak, and sink forty Fathom deep under the Earth.

p.hi: Who so bold, as a blind Byard.

sp.speaker: Carel.
sp.p: Captain, forbear.

sp.speaker: Sir Bar.
sp.p: I have brought my Hogs to a fine Market, this will be The Devil upon Dun.

sp.speaker: Carel.
sp.p: I am glad you are so far a favourer of our cause, to believe Jacinta innocent.

sp.speaker: Lov.
sp.p: I do.

sp.speaker: Carel.
sp.p: But since her Honour and the Family's cannot be held without this Marriage; I press him to that point, thô at the same time, I direct my Sword against the Brother of my Friend, and even against my Friends own breast, for I am sure the Captain won't stand idle.

sp.speaker: Capt.
sp.p: Thô I am not so skill'd in Love, I hope I shall do my part at this sport.

p.hi: This mends like sower Ale in Summer.

sp.speaker: Carel.
sp.p: I think we are all ready.

sp.speaker: Lov.
sp.p: Draw Brother.

sp.speaker: Sir Bar.
sp.p: Hum— humh—

sp.speaker: Carel.
sp.p: Come let's not loose time.

sp.speaker: Lov.
sp.p: Draw Brother, draw.

sp.speaker: Sir Bar.
sp.p: Umh, What's worse than ill luck.

sp.speaker: Lov.
sp.p: What's the matter.

sp.speaker: Sir Bar.
sp.p: My Sword with riding, is grown rusty in the Scabbard. Sir Bar. offers to draw his Sword.

sp.speaker: Carel.
sp.p: Let me see't Sir Barnaby— I'll warrant you.

sp.speaker: Sir Bar.
sp.p: Trust my Sword in an Enemies hand! Whose's the fool than.

sp.speaker: Carel.
sp.p: Cry you mercy. Pulls to get the Sword out.

sp.speaker: Sir Bar.
sp.p: Ay, Cry you mercy, kill'd the Cat.— umh humh.

sp.speaker: Lov.
sp.p: Let me see't— Gentlemen with your patience, I'll speak two words aside to my Brother.

sp.speaker: Capt.
sp.p: Dispatch, dispatch— the winds fair.

sp.speaker: Sir Bar.
sp.p: What a pox— No such hast, to hang true Folk

sp.speaker: Lov.
sp.p: Let us not ingage in an ill cause, if we can help it.

sp.speaker: Sir Bar.
sp.p: I am content to let it alone, tell 'em 'Tis good to have Wit in ones Anger.

sp.speaker: Lov.
sp.p: But you must repair the Ladies Honour.

sp.speaker: Sir Bar.
sp.p: But I'll not take a Lease of her for life, to be bound to repairs, when all the damage has been done by the Tenant at will.

sp.speaker: Lov.
sp.p: Upon my Life and Conscience, I think her very innocent and virtuous▪ Be not abus'd by fond suspitions.

p.hi: One may see light at a little hole.

sp.speaker: Lov.
sp.p: I am confident— she'll make a good Wife.

p.hi: A Vessel will smell of the first Liquor. Once a Whore, and ever a Whore.

sp.speaker: Lov.
sp.p: I have done— we must e'en fight it out, Lovel draws the Sword. there's your Sword. You tremble.

sp.speaker: Sir Bar.
sp.p: It's a little Cold this morning methinks.

sp.speaker: Lov.
sp.p: Cold!

p.hi: May come it early, come it late, it will make the Cow to quake.

sp.speaker: Lov.
sp.p: Since you are afraid, rather than your Honour shall be expos'd— I'll make one Proposal— and let you see, I perswade you to nothing, that I would not do my self— Gentlemen, my Brother cannot Marry the Lady, because his Opinion it not reconcil'd to her Honour; but I have other thoughts of the fair Jacinta, and believe all in her prejudice to be mistakes; therefore if she'll accept me for a Husband; I am ready to do her Justice.

sp.speaker: Carel.
sp.p: I confess you being both of a Family, and Sir Barnaby's Brother, your Marriage gives sufficient Satisfaction.

sp.speaker: Sir Bar.
sp.p: Ay, Any Tooth good Barber, as the case stands with her.

sp.speaker: Carel.
sp.p: But your Estate is not half Sir Barnaby's.

p.hi: There's a spoak put into the Wheel again.

sp.speaker: Lov.
sp.p: The whole comes to me, if he die without Issue.

sp.speaker: Sir Bar.
sp.p: There, He has hit the right nail on the head.

sp.speaker: Carel.
sp.p: He may Marry, and have Children.

sp.speaker: Sir Bar.
sp.p: That Puts his Nose out of joynt again.

sp.speaker: Carel.
sp.p: Yet I'll undertake, let but Sir Barnaby, add to your Six Hundred a Year, four more out of his Estate, during life. And Mr. Alderman shall accept the Change.

sp.speaker: Lov.
sp.p: Come Gentlemen, then let's decide the matter thus: I know my Brother won't be forc'd to any thing.

sp.speaker: Sir Bar.
sp.p: No, All things for Love, nothing by force.

sp.speaker: Carel.
sp.p: What say you Sir Barnaby?

sp.speaker: Sir Bar.
sp.p: I say Sir, I won't be forc'd by any body— nor to any thing— I'll sooner loose a thousand Lives.

sp.speaker: Capt.
sp.p: Well said, old boy; come bowze it away.

sp.speaker: Carel.
sp.p: Come then, Sir, you and I—

sp.speaker: Sir Bar.
sp.p: Nay, Sir, be as angry as you will— I'll speak what I have to say first, and I tell it you to your Teeth, I will not be forced, and yet out of Love and natural affection, to my Brother— and because he likes the Gentlewoman, his fancy shall not be baulk'd. Therefore I will give four Hundred a Year upon that Condition, whether any here will or nill, and let me see who'll say me nay. I can be as chuff as any of you.

sp.speaker: Carel.
sp.p: I beg your pardon, Sir Barnaby; then friendly we embrace, and here let all resentments vanish.

sp.speaker: Capt.
sp.p: What then, do we strike our Flag—

sp.speaker: Lov.
sp.p: Dear Brother, this honourable act surprizes me.

sp.speaker: Capt.
sp.p: No Fighting amongst us, Zouns, aboard a Ship, we had had as many Bullets e'er this, as here has been words.

sp.speaker: Sir Bar.
sp.p: Captain, You need not be so Crusty, you are not so hard bak'd.

sp.speaker: Capt.
sp.p: That's a Land term, now, that I don't understand.

sp.speaker: Hil.
sp.p: Uncle— Uncle, have you any work for a Tinker. The Parson has staid this hour, and has nothing to do— must he be gone, or will you have him stay to say Grace at Dinner?

sp.speaker: Fur.
sp.p: Let him take pains with you, you want Grace.

sp.speaker: Hil.
sp.p: Right, I am not come to't; Uncle, and you are past it, else you'd not be so easily seduc'd to believe Sir Barnaby Belzebub there.

sp.speaker: Fur.
sp.p: Sir Barnaby, here's your Acquittance— I wish the next Lady you Court, may have better luck.

sp.speaker: Carel.
sp.p: Mr. Alderman, Sir Barnaby still retains so great a respect for your Daughter, that if you'll accept Mr. Lovell for her Husband, he offers to settle on him, four Hundred a Year, additional Estate, out of his own, during Life; and you have a prospect for it all hereafter.

sp.speaker: Fur.
sp.p: Will he!

sp.speaker: Sir Bar.
sp.p: Yes,— no offence I hope— I will— What's freer then gift.

sp.speaker: Hil.
sp.p: Now do I hope my Uncle will refuse the offer— and give me all his Money when he Dies, to vex his Daughter.

sp.speaker: Fur.
sp.p: Rather then you shall see a Groat on't, I'll give it to Hospitals, which is the worst use a Man can put his Money too; for the Poor are always cheated on't. Mr. Lovell, I have all I can desire, which is to see my Daughter well disposed off; for your sake I'll add some Hundreds to her Portion— for my Heart is now so much lighter then it was.

sp.speaker: Lov.
sp.p: Sir, I'll study to deserve your kindness. And Brother yours—

sp.speaker: Hil.
sp.p: Lord, Uncle, that you shou'd do all this to spight me.

sp.speaker: Sir Bar.
sp.p: What you do, do with a Jerk, For I▪ ll pack up my Aulls and begone.

sp.speaker: Carel.
sp.p: You'll stay and Dine with us, Sir Barnaby.

sp.speaker: Sir Bar.
sp.p: Ay, ay, Prayer and Provender, ne'er hinder a Journey. While you order your matters, Dash. shall draw a short Article for Memorandum.

sp.speaker: Lov.
sp.p: Then I'll go offer my self at Jacinta's Feet, and ask her consent.

sp.speaker: Carel.
sp.p: Sir, now I have done you a piece of service Sir Bar. and Lov. Ex. severally. please to do me a small kindness in requital.

sp.speaker: Fur.
sp.p: Sir, I must acknowledge your friendship; what is't?

sp.speaker: Carel.
sp.p: To use your Authority with your Neice, and keep her up; for I can be no where, either about my business, or taking my recreation, but she presently comes and disturbs me, she was the occasion of all last Nights bustle.

sp.speaker: Fur.
sp.p: Nay if there's any mischief towards, she's at the end on't I warrant you

sp.speaker: Hil.
sp.p: Ay, but hold Sir, I was at the beginning of that, as you'll hear hereafter.

sp.speaker: Carel.
sp.p: You see how 'tis Sir— If you don't take some speedy course with her, I must be forc'd to leave this Town, to avoid her Company.

sp.speaker: Fur.
sp.p: Pray take her along with you, and you'll free me of a great trouble, for she has been my vexation some Years.

sp.speaker: Hil.
sp.p:
'Tis true, that Gentleman and I have been a little troublesome to one another; you know he came to sollicite 〈◊〉 in the way of Matrimony, which I don't much approve of; for it makes Folk's fall out. The first Day of Marriage is the last Day of Love. 〈◊〉 lik'd him well enough for a Gallant, and
if he wou'd have accepted of me for a Mistress, or so; we might have fadg'd a while, but he had a foolish scruple of Conscience, nothing wou'd serve him but Marriage, and so away came I, this is all Uncle.

sp.speaker: Capt.
sp.p: I shall never learn to know at Land, whether they are in earnest, either in talking or fighting.

sp.speaker: Fur.
sp.p: If you will have my Opinion in the case, you were cut out, one for the other; and 'tis pity two Houses should part you. Therefore if she'll agree to your desire, or you conform to her's, 'tis all one to me, you have my consent to either. All I ask is, that you'll make an end quickly, that I may be clear of her Company.

sp.speaker: Hil.
sp.p: Then, Sir, you may either go to London, or stay in the Country, if you please, without danger of being troubled with me; for I absolutely declare against Marriage; and if nothing else will serve your turn, you may go when you will, where you will, and do what you please; I'll have nothing to say to such an unreasonable Man as you are.

sp.speaker: Carel.
sp.p: To convince you Mr. Alderman, that what she says is not true, but that on the contrary, I am for having her for a Mistress, and she is for being my Wife: Mr. Lovell, and the Captain, and all that know me, can witness, I have continually rail'd against Marrying.

sp.speaker: Fur.
sp.p: Well, I'll leave you to decide the matter betwixt your selves. Fur. Ex.

sp.speaker: Capt.
sp.p: Yes, yes, I have heard you forswear Marrying, and drinking too▪ yet I catch you dabling in the Punch bowl next day.

sp.speaker: Carel.
sp.p: Now Lady, if you are not for what I propos'd, you may e'en live a Maid. and Die a Fool, or live a Fool, and Die a Maid; your Epitaph shall be the same.

sp.speaker: Hil.
sp.p: I except against your Sex for Witnesses, as byast. But rather then such a lyiny Man as you shall have it, my Maidenhead and I will Live and Die together, be buryed both in a Grave, that you may be chief Mourner at my Funeral. So farewell you Matrimonial Fop.

sp.speaker: Carel.
sp.p: Pray—

sp.speaker: Hil.
sp.p: No, there's a Wedding going forward within, and I would not loose the diversion of that silly sight, to hear all you can say. Hil. Exit.

sp.speaker: Carel.
sp.p: Come Captain, we'll go see how scurvily it looks in others, that it may be a warning for us, to avoid it too. But this I'll say,

lg.l: If for a Wife my liberty I loose,
This is the Girl must catch me in the noose. Cap. Carel. Ex.

div.head: SCENE VII.

sp.speaker: Greed.
sp.p: Send away Dinner— send away Dinner, there a pox upon them all for loytering Rogues, why don't you send Dinner away, I must e'en sit me down, for I am almost spent with running and bawling after one and another.

sp.speaker: 1 Inn.
sp.p: Lord, Sir, you have no patience, here's a noise, as if the great Bell rung out for the Towns being on Fire, and your Tongue was the Clapper.

sp.speaker: Greed.
sp.p: It must Ring out, when my Belly Rings Noon; the bak'd Meats run out, the Pottages boyl o'er, and the Roast'd will be dry'd to Powder.

sp.speaker: 1 Inn.
sp.p:
Who can help it— Sir Barnaby himself gave order for Dinner to be ready by Eleven of the Clock, the Clock has made all hast possible. They
within are at better for worse— the words are not quite out of their Mouths yet: why, your Worship is a Man of no moderation?

sp.speaker: Greed.
sp.p: Well, well, they have done by this time,— good host, see it be sent to Table, my Spirits are almost spent.

sp.speaker: 1 Inn.
sp.p: It shall, Sir, it shall.

sp.speaker: Greed.
sp.p: Bid my Clark be ready to attend me. Innkeeper Exit.

sp.speaker: 1 Inn.
sp.p: Yes, Sir.

sp.speaker: Greed.
sp.p: Oh, Mr. Dash.— has the Parson done the jobb.

sp.speaker: Dash.
sp.p: Yes, Sir.

sp.speaker: Greed.
sp.p: What a sudden change of affairs is here, this good Dinner was provided for Sir Barnaby's Wedding Dinner— and is now serv'd up for Mr. Lovell's Bride, and all falls to his share.

sp.speaker: Dash.
sp.p: Much good do him with her, that has her; I am glad Sir Barnaby mist her.

sp.speaker: Greed.
sp.p: But what do I prating here, when Dinners going up.

sp.speaker: Dash.
sp.p: Gemminy Sir, how you are garnish'd out, as if you were to be serv'd up for a standing Dish— more for ornament, than use— let me help you off with your Cloak. Some body has pin'd a dish clout to your back.

sp.speaker: Greed.
sp.p: Whose Roguery was this, the Cooks or the Boys; I'll have 'em all to the whipping post, for abusing a publick Magistrate.

sp.speaker: Dash.
sp.p: Look you Sir, they have pin'd a dish clout to your back, and the Cape is stuck with staring Feathers— like a French hen.

sp.speaker: Greed.
sp.p: Help me— they'll have din'd else before I come.

sp.speaker: Dash.
sp.p: Sir. Mr. Alderman sent me to acquaint you, that a Lord, and a Coach full of Ladies— of his acquaintance, Just now are come into bait, whom he could not but invite to dine with him— therefore makes bold with you as his special good friend, the Table being but little to have a a Cloath laid in another Room.

sp.speaker: Greed.
sp.p: How, not dine within, after all my care!

sp.speaker: Dash.
sp.p: Sir, he desires you to see Dinner sent up in good order, and me to attend at Table. Your Worship may for once dispence with your Magistracy, and sit with me and the waiting Gentlewoman; I don't like Dineing amongst great Gentry, 'tis not mannerly to fill one's belly before 'em.

sp.speaker: Greed.
sp.p: Well, there shall not a Dish escape me— and now I think on't, I can there take my own time; and gorge at leisure.

sp.speaker: Dash.
sp.p: So Sir, you may now put on your Cloak— only take a view of your Hat, that Cock's Tail in't makes you look like a City Train-band Captain.

sp.speaker: Greed.
sp.p: Wou'd I knew whose Roguery it was.

sp.speaker: Dash.
sp.p: Look you Sir, here's the first Dish come from the Table already.

sp.speaker: Greed.
sp.p: Prithee go and call my Clerk to me. Dash Exit. Hold, hold, you Sir— whether go you with that?

sp.speaker: 1 Boy.
sp.p: To the Kitchen, Sir.

sp.speaker: Greed.
sp.p: No, no, set it down here— So— Enter 2 d Boy with a Dish, and sets it down. Ay, ay, and you there— here, here— set it down here—

sp.speaker: 2 Boy.
sp.p: The Dogs will come to't there.

sp.speaker: Greed.
sp.p: Go Knave, go, what serve I for?

sp.speaker: 2 Boy.
sp.p: Indeed, Sir, they will.

sp.speaker: Greed.
sp.p: No, no.

sp.speaker: 1 Boy.
sp.p: A Greyhound, as I came a long, chop'd a great Mary-bone out of my Dish, and ran away with it.

sp.speaker: Greed.
sp.p: Send him to me then: I'll lay the Dog by the heels. Sets the Dish down.

sp.speaker: 2 Boy.
sp.p: Come Tom. Boys Exeunt.

sp.speaker: Greed.
sp.p: Let me see; what's here— O— the Toasts and Marybones: Marrow's a delicate food; the very Quintescence of the Ox— it Oyls the Chops rarely— and makes Dinner go glibly down.

div.stage: Enter Dash and John with two Dishes.

sp.speaker: Greed.
sp.p: You Sir, come here— John, set your Dish down too— we'll not trust any thing into the Kitchin till we have Din'd, the Rogues there will be Liquorish and light Finger'd.

sp.speaker: Dash.
sp.p: Your Worship speaks discreetly. Exit.

sp.speaker: Greed.
sp.p: I know the tricks of Servants— John, where's the Cloak-Bag?

div.stage: Exit John, and enter again with the Cloak-Bag.

sp.speaker: John.
sp.p: Just here Sir.

sp.speaker: Greed.
sp.p: Let me see— that's a Pottage— this a Dish of Scotch Collops— this a Frigacy of Chickens— well relish'd on my word; this fellow, Sawce, were an excellent Cook was he not so cross and cholerick. Hold the Bag, John, is there a clean Napkin in it?

sp.speaker: John.
sp.p: Yes Sir.

sp.speaker: Greed.
sp.p: 'Twill stand us in use now: Let me see, suppose we put in two or three Marybones— Ay, they are full— remove the Dishes into the next Room there, and as I send the rest into you, put in some of the best of every thing, but not so as to unfurnish quite the Dishes.

div.stage: Enter Dash with a large Dish.

sp.speaker: Dash.
sp.p: Sir, here's the Venison Pasty scarce touch'd.

sp.speaker: Greed.
sp.p: Let me see't— O rare— carry't in there. Dash Exit, into the By-room. O rare, fat Venison; ay, there's a substantial Dish, the Glory of England— Mr. Dash! Re-enter Dash. Have they almost Din'd?

sp.speaker: Dash.
sp.p: Yes Sir. Dash Exit.

sp.speaker: Greed.
sp.p: John, John, put in a good deal of the Pasty, cut off a lusty corner; take the fattest of the Venison; and do you hear me, a swinging deal of Pudding Crust. Enter 1 st Boy and 2 d with Dishes.

sp.speaker: 1 st Boy.
sp.p: Sir, must we set these down here too? The Boy snatches out of the Dish a Lobster, and runs; Greedy after him; in the mean time the 2 d steals a Pheasant, Greedy after him, and tumbles down top of one the other; the Boy gets away with.

sp.speaker: Greed.
sp.p: Ay, ay, John, John, take in these things here— Ha! are you at your Legerdemain?— Stop Thief, stop Thief.

sp.speaker: 1 st Boy.
sp.p: A Pox of your Clutches.

sp.speaker: Greed.
sp.p: Hey, another Felon— Sirrah, Sirrah, come here— Come here Sirrah▪

sp.speaker: 2 d Boy.
sp.p: O murder! murder!

sp.speaker: Greed.
sp.p: Sirrah let go, 'tis Felony, thou'lt be hang'd else: Call in the servants, make fresh pursuit— send Hue and Cry after the Rogue.

sp.speaker: John.
sp.p: What's the matter Sir?

sp.speaker: Greed.
sp.p: O that Villanous Boy has murder'd me, he's run away with a Pheasant. John, and this Leg is all that's left of the Lobster. O never will my Belly forgive my hands, that cou'd not hold it.— Here, put this Leg of the Lobster into the Cloak-Bag— bring it forth, and let me see how thou hast stor'd it.— Oh these unlucky Bastards, I am almost swelter'd— John brings in the Cloak bag. Let me see what's this.

sp.speaker: John.
sp.p: Some of the Pasty.

sp.speaker: Greed.
sp.p: Ay, well— but what hast thou done here? Puts his finger into the bag, and licks twice or thrice. What's this Pottage— Pottage—

sp.speaker: John.
sp.p: Yes Sir— there's a good deal of it in—

sp.speaker: Greed.
sp.p: Oh Rogue! Villain! put Pottage into my Cloak-bag!

sp.speaker: John.
sp.p: 'Tis very good, 'twill do no hurt I warrant you.

sp.speaker: Greed.
sp.p: O Nonsensical Ass— thou hast spoil'd all: O what do I suffer, the Lobster broken, the Pheasant gone; how many afflictions befal me in one day. Here, lead me into the next Room; I'll sit me down and sigh till my heart breaks, for surely I can never survive all this.

sp.speaker: John.
sp.p: Pray, Sir, have patience.

sp.speaker: Greed.
sp.p: No, no, my stomach's gone with vexing. I am a dead man, I shall never eat again.— There, there— bring in the Cloak-bag, and my Cloak with it. Oh.— Exeunt. John carries off the Cloak and Cloak-bag.

div.head: SCENE VIII.
div.stage: Enter Mr. Alderman Fur, Sir Barnaby, Lovell, Captain Careless, Jacinta, Hilaria, Arabella, Mrs. Breeder, and Mrs. Dazie.

sp.speaker: Fur.
sp.p: I am glad our Guests are gone.— Now, Mr. Lovell, I wish you much joy with my Daughter— may you live happy together.

sp.speaker: Sir Barn.
sp.p: So do I, but marry in haste and repent at leisure.

sp.speaker: Lov.
sp.p: The marriage seldom knows repentance where both parties are pleas'd.

sp.speaker: Sir Barn.
sp.p: All's well that ends well; I say, the proof of the Pudding is in the Eating. So rest you merry.

sp.speaker: Carel.
sp.p: Sir Barnaby, two words ere you go; 'tis not convenient you shou'd depart under the scandal of a Licentious Bastard-getter, therefore that you may go with as clear a reputation as you came, I declare these two here were set on by some that I know, to bring you in disrepute with Mr. Alderman and his Daughter.— Farther they confess, that the old Justice shifted them out of his Room into yours this morning by accident. So you are clear'd from two scandals, and three Children, at once.

sp.speaker: Dazie & Breed.
sp.p: All this we own.

sp.speaker: Sir Barn.
sp.p: Well said: When the Frier's beaten then comes Jack.

sp.speaker: Hil.
sp.p: Look you Sir, these are the Clothes you found in my Cozens Chamber, which we borrow'd of those two young Youths that came down with us yesterday in the other Stage-Coach, and are going into France with their Governor to Travel; these we put on out of a frolick. I undress'd in her Chamber; and I was that little Fornicator that so kiss'd and caress'd her in her bed. This Uncle, I hope, will ease your mind, and reconcile Sir Barnaby to the Bride's reputation.

p.hi: Tittle Tattle, give the Goose more Hay.

sp.speaker: Carel.
sp.p: Nay, Sir, the Captain and I are Witnesses to this matter.

p.hi: Ask my fellow if I am a Thief.

sp.speaker: Fur.
sp.p: 'Tis like enough, my Niece is seldom without an unlucky frolick.

sp.speaker: Sir Barn.
sp.p: Then she's like Goodyears Pig, always doing mischief.

sp.speaker: Hil.
sp.p: We— we— we—

sp.speaker: Omn.
sp.p: Ha, ha, ha—

sp.speaker: Sir Barn.
sp.p: I shall meet some of you either at Hedge or Stile— and so let them laugh that win— Exit Sir Barn.

sp.speaker: Omn.
sp.p: Ha, ha, ha.

sp.speaker: Hil.
sp.p: Sir Barnaby, Sir Barnaby, remember Waltoms Calfe— Farewel Frost—

sp.speaker: Lov.
sp.p: I'll see him mounted for his last kindness. Exeunt Lovell and Arabella.

sp.speaker: Arab.
sp.p: I must bid him farewel too.

sp.speaker: Fur.
sp.p: I am glad he miss'd my Daughter; I like neither his person nor humor. Come, now I'll lead you the way in— we'll have the Musick and be merry.

sp.speaker: Hil.
sp.p: Hold, hold, Uncle; you are for rising from Table before Dinner's done— here's another Course yet to come up: The Parson must say Grace once more.

sp.speaker: Carel.
sp.p: Lead on, Sir; pray lead on— here's a Plot upon me.

sp.speaker: Hil.
sp.p: Come, come, Careless, ne'er halt before a Cripple.

sp.speaker: Carel.
sp.p: O Madam, you are a dangerous Person, I dare not trust my self with you alone.

sp.speaker: Fur.
sp.p: Niece, what say you to me?

sp.speaker: Hil.
sp.p: It comes just now in my mind that I have lost my Bedfellow, and now my Cozen is marry'd I know not what to do, for I vow I dare not lye alone.

sp.speaker: Carel.
sp.p: O no, 'tis dangerous; for after seeing marriages, and a new married Couple put to Bed together, as strange dreams and fancies will be apt to run in your mind, as after seeing Executions and dead People; and who knows what a taking you may be in i'th' Night, and what strange fits you may have.

sp.speaker: Hil.
sp.p: O Sir, do you begin to come about; wou'd you beat off others that you may be my Bedfellow your self? I perceive now that you are for having a Wife.

sp.speaker: Carel.
sp.p: I for a Wife?

sp.speaker: Hil.
sp.p: Madam, you come just in the nick of time, to see a poor distressed Damesel throw her self away— Well Sir, give me your hand, rather than lye alone to Night I'll do any thing.

sp.speaker: Carel.
sp.p: I knew 'twou'd come to this.

sp.speaker: Hil.
sp.p: I will be you Wife; and since I cant't have a Gallant before marriage, I'll do like other Wives, and have one after. And now I think on't too, a Husband's very necessary to keep off a scandal; and besides, what Children the Gallant gets, the Husband must keep.

sp.speaker: Fur.
sp.p: You are like to have a hopeful Wife.

sp.speaker: Carel.
sp.p: I can be even with her there.— Look you Madam, you can bring me none to keep but what are my own; and if you expect I shou'd be a Father to all your Children, I expect you shou'd be a Nurse to all mine, and I may have 'em brought home to me on all sides; for I intent to be a great getter, and the Father of many. Is it a bargain?

sp.speaker: Hil.
sp.p: It is: Here, lewd Fellow, here's my hand on't, Heav'n send thee good luck, for I shall be a plague to thee as long as I live.

sp.speaker: Lov.
sp.p: This is fair play on both sides.

sp.speaker: Hil.
sp.p: This 'tis for folks to meet that understand themselves. Captain, what think you of this?

sp.speaker: Lov.
sp.p: He's in a deep Contemplation of Love too.

sp.speaker: Durz.
sp.p: Yes, and this is the very thing I love.

sp.speaker: Arab.
sp.p: Let not such idle thoughts trouble your head, I am almost weary on't my self.

sp.speaker: Durz.
sp.p: Say you so?

sp.speaker: Arab.
sp.p: Yes, you and I will be friends for all that, such a trifle as love shall break no squares. So Captain, tack about to the next.

sp.speaker: Durz.
sp.p: But by your leave, 'tis more honorable to stand into rights than to make a tack, and say and sing the Devil's head off. I will judge of Love by the Rules of Honor; therefore sink or swim, I'll bear up close with you.

sp.speaker: Carel.
sp.p: Well said old Buccanier.

sp.speaker: Arab.
sp.p: I like a man of resolution well; then here's my hand, my trusty Tarpaulin, you shall find me no flincher neither. And now Captain, we are sailing out of the Haven of Love into the Tempestuous Sea of Matrimony.

sp.speaker: Durz.
sp.p: So, at last I have gotten the Weather-gage of her, and now I'll lay her thwart the Harser and Board her to rights.

sp.speaker: Hil.
sp.p: Now Uncle, pray Con o'er our Agreement, for you are to be Summon'd for a Witness upon occasion.

sp.speaker: Fur.
sp.p: It is like to be a fine marriage.

sp.speaker: Lov.
sp.p: Yes, if it go on as you begun.

sp.speaker: Carel.
sp.p: You shall see our marriage (which you think clap'd up out of a frolick) go on more chearfully than yours made out of stark Love and desperate Affection; we, like two Birds, tho' we Roost together at Night, will have our freedom all day, and fly chirping about, whil'st you, like two Domestick Animals, coupled too close together, shall still be sharling and biting one at another.

sp.speaker: Hil.
sp.p: And we have the trouble every now and then to part you. Mark the end on't.

sp.speaker: Carel.
sp.p: Mrs. Breeder and Mrs. Dazie, your good service shall be rewarded; let none of your Function think they have lost me because I am married, I am enter'd into matrimony but not into bondage.

sp.speaker: Hil.
sp.p: He has, as it were, but one Mistress the more.— Lead away Uncle.

lg.l: Whil'st other Wives and Husbands Scold and Rant,
We two will live like Mistress and Gallant. Exeunt.

div.head: EPILOGUE.
div.l: FRom Elbow Chair i'th' Pantry I am come,
To see what you are doing here; make room.
So heartily I slept after my Labor,
My Nose did louder Musick make than Pipe and Tabor.
My Dreams presented me a Bill of Fare,
Of sumptuous Meat and Dainties that were rare:
I wak'd with joy, and to my comfort find,
Three Couple here in Bonds of Wedlock joyn'd.
Three days we'll Feast, a day for every Pair,
And each days Management shall be my care:
We'll have our swinge of Mirth, let nothing cross it,
For ev'ry Bride I'll provide a good Sack-Posset,
With grated Naples-Bisket made, and yolks
Of new-laid Eggs, Salacious Food for marry'd Folks:
It shall be rich with Ambergreese and Pounded Pearls,
Which shall provoke a Race of lusty Boys and Girls:
A Bridal Cake for each one too to Munch on,
And every Guest shall have a lusty Lunchon.
All that are here for Guests I do invite;
We'll treat the first, the second, and third Night;
With all the choicest Dainties I will feed ye:
